Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: There are two general requirements for piercing the corporate veil: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Res judicata did not prohibit amendment of judgment to add debtor, under alter ego theory, who was successful in underlying arbitration.

Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The essence of the alter ego doctrine is that justice be done; liability is imposed to reach an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Res judicata did not prohibit amendment of judgment to add debtor, under alter ego theory, who was successful in underlying arbitration.

Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The corporate form will be disregarded under the alter ego doctrine only in narrowly defined circumstances and only when the ends of justice so require.

Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Because it is founded on equitable principles, application of the alter ego doctrine is not made to depend upon prior decisions involving factual situations which appear to be similar.

Title: Sykes v. Mel Harris and Associates, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts may pierce corporate veil and disregard corporate form whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.

Title: Sykes v. Mel Harris and Associates, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must show: (1) that business entity and its owner operated as single economic entity, and (2) overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Consumers alleged that debt-buying company, debt collection agency, and process service company engaged in RICO enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lake City Janitorial, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In action to "pierce the corporate veil," plaintiffs must allege that (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) circumstances are such that an adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequitable consequences; courts consider laundry list of factors to determine whether there is "unity of interest" between two corporations or between a corporation and a controlling shareholder, but focus is on whether corporations have respected corporate formalities--respected their separateness from each other, or whether one was sham acting at whim of the other.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Common law fraud claim against corporations' owner was not preempted by ERISA or LMRA and was pled with enough particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sullivan v. Sullivan
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Equity will not allow a corporate veil to cover fraud or injustice, and to prevent such the corporate entity may be disregarded and the corporation and individual or individuals owning all of its stock and assets treated as identical.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Attorney Fees. Award of appellate attorney fees was warranted as sanction for former husband's unsupported appeal from contempt order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hamilton Partners, L.P. v. Englard
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: A corporation chartering state has a substantial interest in preventing the corporate form from becoming a shield for unfair business dealing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Chancery Court had specific personal jurisdiction under long-arm statute over principal beneficiary of transaction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: CAO Holdings, Inc. v. Trost
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Nashville.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a court must be convinced that the separate corporate entity is a sham or a dummy or that disregarding the separate corporate entity is necessary to accomplish justice.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Judgment. Genuine issue of material fact as to whether corporate jet was used exclusively for renting or leasing precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: CAO Holdings, Inc. v. Trost
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Nashville.
Headnote: In analyzing whether a corporation's separate legal identity should be ignored, it is not necessary that all factors weigh in favor of piercing the corporate veil; but, it is necessary that the equities substantially favor the party requesting the court to disregard the corporate status.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Judgment. Genuine issue of material fact as to whether corporate jet was used exclusively for renting or leasing precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil under Pennsylvania law, courts are basically concerned with determining if equity requires that the shareholders' traditional insulation from personal liability be disregarded and with ascertaining if the corporate form is a sham, constituting a facade for the operations of the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Complaint failed to state veil-piercing claim against wife of debtors' principal.

Title: Michiana Dairy Processors, LLC v. All Star Beverage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Hammond Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil bears burden of establishing that corporation was so ignored, controlled or manipulated that it was merely instrumentality of another, and that misuse of corporate form would constitute fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Genssler v. Harris County
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: The alter ego theory allows the individual to be liable for the business entity when there is such a unity between the business entity and the individual that the business entity has ceased to be a separate entity, and allowing the individual to avoid liability through the use of the business entity would work an injustice.

Title: Tucker v. American Intern. Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, courts disregard fiction of separate legal entity to pierce shield of immunity afforded by corporate structure in situation in which corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on real actor.

Title: Breen v. Judge

Title: Breen v. Judge
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Ordinarily, the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Casa de Meadows Inc. (Cayman Islands) v. Zaman

Headnote: Evidence of domination alone does not suffice to pierce corporate veil without additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.

Title: Motorola Credit Corp. v. Uzan

Headnote: Under New York law, while complete domination of corporation is key to piercing corporate veil, especially when owners use corporation as mere device to further their personal rather than corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.

Title: Lakeview Commons v. Empower Yourself

Title: In re Broadstripe, LLC

Title: Latham v. Burgher

Title: In re Ryan

Title: In re Ryan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Fort Worth Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, sham to perpetrate fraud is an equitable doctrine, and, in applying it, Texas courts take a flexible, fact-specific approach focusing on equity. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Homeowners failed to establish alter ego as basis for piercing corporate veil and holding debtor personally liable for debts.

Title: Ottens v. McNeil
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded when there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and the observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or an inequitable result would follow.

Title: Hub City Solid Waste Services, Inc. v. City of Compton
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked: first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist; second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Waste management company officer bribed city officials to obtain franchise to operate city waste services.

Title: Hub City Solid Waste Services, Inc. v. City of Compton
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil is justified as an equitable remedy when the shareholders have abused the corporate form to evade individual liability, circumvent a statute, or accomplish a wrongful purpose.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Waste management company officer bribed city officials to obtain franchise to operate city waste services.

Title: Federal Nat. Mortg. Ass'n v. Olympia Mortg. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Ordinarily under New York law, the shareholders of a corporation are not personally liable for obligations incurred by that corporation; however, where the owners, through their domination of the corporation, abuse the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against a party, a court in equity will intervene and pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fannie Mae was entitled to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder responsible for lender's liability in contract action.

Title: In re Cyberco Holdings, Inc.

Headnote: General principle in Michigan is that separate corporate entities will be respected, and thus corporate veils will be pierced only to prevent fraud or injustice.

Title: Macquarie Bank Ltd. v. Knickel
Court: United States District Court, D. North Dakota, Northwestern Division.
Headnote: There must be "an element of injustice, inequity or fundamental unfairness" present before the court may properly pierce the corporate veil under North Dakota law, and burden of establishing the necessary elements for piercing the corporate veil rests with the moving party.

Title: Blair v. Infineon Technologies AG
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the possibility that a plaintiff may have difficulty enforcing a judgment is not an injustice warranting piercing the corporate veil.

Title: LDT Keller Farms, LLC v. Brigitte Holmes Livestock Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Fort Wayne Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, where it is clear that a corporation is merely a shell for conducting the defendant's own business, and where the misuse of the corporate form constitutes a fraud or promotes injustice, the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil may be invoked to disregard the corporate entity and hold shareholders personally liable for the actions of the corporation.

Title: Wordtech Systems, Inc v. Integrated Networks Solutions, Inc.

Headnote: Generally, a Nevada court may exert its equitable powers and disregard the corporate entity if it decides that piercing the veil will prevent fraud, illegality, injustice, a contravention of public policy, or prevent the corporation from shielding someone from criminal liability.

Headnote: Under Michigan law, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate where there is evidence of fraud, illegality, or injustice.

Title: In re Smith
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, in order to pierce corporate veil on an alter ego theory, plaintiff must prove: (1) that there was such a unity of ownership and interest between corporation and its owners that their separateness ceased to exist; and (2) that recognition of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Smith
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, in order to pierce corporate veil on instrumentality theory, plaintiff must prove: (1) that corporation was mere instrumentality of shareholder; (2) that shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a way as to defraud or harm the plaintiff; and (3) that refusal to disregard corporate entity would subject plaintiff to unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misuse of company funds was in nature of embezzlement or larceny.

Title: Charter Services, Inc. v. DL Air, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: In Delaware, courts disregard the corporate form and individuals will be held personally liable in the interest of justice, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract, public wrong, or where equitable consideration among members of the corporation require it, are involved.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hershey v. Edelman
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: A shareholder can be held responsible for a corporation's debts, based on piercing of the corporate veil, when: (1) the shareholder's control over the corporation was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) the shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Civil claim for losses from criminal falsification could not be brought independently of criminal proceedings.

Title: In re Jarvar
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Montana courts consider two factors in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the corporation is the alter ego of the individual, and (2) there must be a showing that the corporate entity was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud.

Title: A.P.I., Inc. v. Home Ins. Co.

Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Ordinarily the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and is used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts decline to pierce the veil of even the closest corporations in the absence of proof that failure to do so will perpetrate a fraud or other injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ireland v. Dodson
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, corporate veil can be disregarded when it is used as cloak or cover for fraud or illegality, or if necessary to achieve equity.

Title: Partners Coffee Co., LLC v. Oceana Services and Products Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, a court will not hesitate to pierce the corporate veil and treat as identical the corporation and the individuals owning all its stocks and assets whenever justice and public policy demand.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Gist of the action doctrine did not bar fraud-in-the-inducement counterclaim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Carlson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, two requirements must be met to disregard the form of the corporate entity and impose personal liability on the shareholder: first, plaintiff must prove a unity of interest and ownership such that separate legal personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, and, second, plaintiff must show that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation, an inequitable result would follow or that it would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Creditor did not justifiably rely on manager's misrepresentation concerning replacement of pick-up truck's converter.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Pisculli
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that complete domination was exercised over corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against party, which resulted in party's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Statute dealing with property of postconversion estate did not bar objection to discharge on postpetition transfer theory.

Title: Grotenhuis v. County of Santa Barbara

Headnote: The corporate alter ego theory, which is generally used to prevent a fraud and impute liability, lies only in narrowly defined circumstances and only when the ends of justice so require.

Headnote: Under New York law, the party seeking to pierce a corporate veil must make a two-part showing: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.

Headnote: Under Michigan law, there is a presumption that the corporate form will be respected, and this presumption, often referred to as a "corporate veil," may be pierced only where an otherwise separate corporate existence has been used to subvert justice or cause a result that is contrary to some other clearly overriding public policy.

Title: International Millennium Consultants, Inc. v. Taycom Business Solutions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Michigan courts will not pierce the corporate veil unless (1) the corporate entity was a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual; (2) the corporate entity was used to commit a fraud or wrong; and (3) the plaintiff suffered an unjust loss.

Title: Bear, Inc. v. Smith

Headnote: Under the alter ego theory for holding the shareholders of a corporation responsible for corporate liabilities, a plaintiff must prove: (1) that the corporation is not only influenced by the owners, but also that there is such unity of ownership and interest that their separateness has ceased; and (2) that the facts are such that treatment of the corporation as a separate entity would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Bear, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Under the instrumentality theory for holding the shareholders of a corporation responsible for corporate liabilities, the plaintiff must establish three elements to warrant a piercing of the corporate veil: (1) that the corporation was a mere instrumentality of the shareholder; (2) that the shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a way as to defraud or to harm the plaintiff; and (3) that a refusal to disregard the corporate entity would subject the plaintiff to unjust loss.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Dissolution and Survival. Company that operated fuel station had no affirmative duty to notify its creditors of dissolution.

Title: MacDonald v. Summit Orthopedics, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under the second prong of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under Minnesota law, a court analyzes whether the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has established that doing so is necessary to avoid an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.

Title: Spagnola v. Chubb Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To establish that shielding a shareholder from liability for a corporation's actions would result in injustice or fundamental unfairness, as required to properly plead alter-ego liability under Minnesota or Indiana law, proof of strict common law fraud is not required, but, rather, evidence that the corporate entity has been operated as a constructive fraud or in an unjust manner must be presented.

Title: White v. Marshall

Title: Reinhart v. Boeck
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate entities do not commit fraud, but corporate officers, agents, and employees do; hence, while courts are generally reluctant to disregard the corporate identity, they will do so to protect third parties from fraud or injustice when transacting business with a corporate entity.

Title: U.S. S.E.C. v. Levine

Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, with respect to the second factor required to pierce the corporate veil, namely, a showing of unfairness or injustice, while a showing of fraud is not necessary, the requisite injustice or unfairness is also not simple in nature but, rather, something that is similar in nature to fraud or a sham.

Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, with respect to the second factor required to pierce the corporate veil, namely, a showing of unfairness or injustice, the fraud or similar injustice must be found in the defendants' use of the corporate form; in other words, the underlying cause of action, at least by itself, does not supply the necessary fraud or injustice, as to hold otherwise would render the fraud or injustice element meaningless and would sanction bootstrapping.

Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: To determine whether it is appropriate to pierce the corporate veil, a court must make a three-part inquiry: first, the court must determine whether the corporate entity is the "alter ego" of the person or entity in issue; second, the court must determine whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the person or entity sought to be held liable and the corporation over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim; and third, the court must consider whether an equitable result will be achieved by disregarding the corporate form and holding a shareholder or other insider personally liable for the acts of the business entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: The paramount goal of piercing the corporate veil is to achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: McCallum Family L.L.C. v. Winger
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: The second prong of the veil-piercing inquiry, that the court must determine whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the person or entity sought to be held liable and the corporation over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim, reflects a recognition that the corporate veil may be pierced only when the corporate form was used to shield a dominant shareholder's improprieties.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. The burden of proof in an action to pierce the corporate veil is by a preponderance of the evidence.

Title: Khan v. Douglas Machine & Tool Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate entities are presumed to be distinct and veil piercing is only appropriate when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Subordination agreement prevented debenture holder from bringing an action to enforce the debenture.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: McAnaney v. Astoria Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York., E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, two elements must be shown in order to pierce the corporate veil: (1) that the owner exercised complete dominion over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Mortgagors' claim against mortgagees under New York Real Property Law was preempted by Home Owners' Loan Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: In traditional veil-piercing cases, Minnesota courts apply a two-prong test, with the first prong focusing on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation and the second examining whether piercing the corporate veil is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor could not reverse-pierce corporate veil to claim Minnesota homestead exemption in property owned by LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Hecker
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, piercing of the corporate veil is a doctrine that has evolved to treat creditors equitably.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor could not reverse-pierce corporate veil to claim Minnesota homestead exemption in property owned by LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Blue Star Corp. v. CKF Properties, LLC
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and disregard the corporate entity, a plaintiff must establish that: (1) the defendant abused the privilege of a separate corporate identity, and (2) an unjust or inequitable result would occur if the court recognized the separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Purchaser was not estopped from asserting right to removal of tenants and did not waive right in suit against vendor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Shkolnik v. Krutoy
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the law permits the incorporation of a business for the very purpose of escaping personal liability, equity will intervene to pierce the corporate veil and permit the imposition of personal liability in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Defendants failed to make prima facie showing of entitlement to judgment as a matter of law on breach of contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Shkolnik v. Krutoy
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the owners of the corporation exercised complete domination over it in the transaction at issue, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff under circumstances that constitute an abuse of the privilege of doing business in the corporate form.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Defendants failed to make prima facie showing of entitlement to judgment as a matter of law on breach of contract claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Saba Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under second prong of three-prong analysis for corporate veil piercing claim under Colorado law, court must determine whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the shareholder/parent and corporation over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Chapter 7 trustee satisfied fraud pleading rule in asserting actual fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Saba Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, under Colorado law, if adherence to the corporate fiction would promote injustice, protect fraud, defeat a legitimate claim, or defend crime, the invocation of equitable principles for the imposition of personal liability through piercing of the corporate veil may occur.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Chapter 7 trustee satisfied fraud pleading rule in asserting actual fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego doctrine applies where there is such a unity between corporation and individual that separateness of corporation has ceased, and where holding only corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, focus of sham to perpetrate a fraud doctrine is not on relationship between corporation and its owners, but on injustice or unfairness to claimant caused by corporation and its owners.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hodak v. Madison Capital Management, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Kentucky courts are generally reluctant to disregard the corporate entity; corporate veil should not be pierced unless there is (1) such a unity of ownership and interest that the separate personalities of the corporation and its owner cease to exist, and (2) the facts are such that an adherence to the normal attributes of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Fact issue existed as to CEO's claim that company breached employment agreement by terminating him without cause or notice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re KJK Const. Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, a corporate entity will be disregarded, and its veil of limited liability pierced, when two requirements are met: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, and (2) adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote an injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Factual issues precluded summary judgment for defendants on Chapter 7 trustee's fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, the standard test for piercing the corporate veil is two-pronged: (1) plaintiff must demonstrate both that there is such unity of interest and ownership between the individual or entity and the corporation that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual or entity no longer exist, and (2) adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted to recover unpaid contributions to union-administered pension and welfare funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. Bigalk
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, the determination of whether an entity is the alter ego of an individual entails a two-step analysis: first, courts consider the relationship between the individual and the entity, focusing on such factors as the failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, siphoning of funds by the individual, absence of records for the entity, and the existence of the entity as merely a facade for the individual, and second, courts consider the relationship between the entity and the party that seeks to disregard it, disregarding the entity only if it has operated in a fraudulent or unjust manner toward that party.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Transfer of farm to business trust was fraudulent conveyance under Minnesota law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bravado Intern. Group Merchandising Services, Inc. v. Ninna, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: While there are no strict requirements under New York law that must be satisfied before a court may exercise the power to pierce the corporate veil, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Injunction. Defaulting competitors intended to frustrate any judgment or show contempt for judicial process.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Auginaush v. Medure
Court: White Earth Band of Chippewa Tribal Court, Civil Division.
Headnote: Courts will pierce the corporate veil if an entity ignores corporate formalities and acts as the alter ego or instrumentality of a shareholder and the liability limitations of the corporate form results in injustice or is fundamentally unfair.
Document Preview: NATIVE AMERICANS - Gaming. Tribal court had jurisdiction over tribe's claims against non-member gaming corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Board of Managers of 195 Hudson Street Condominium v. Jeffrey M. Brown Associates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Liability via piercing of corporate veil under New York law may be predicated either upon showing of fraud or upon complete control by dominating corporation that leads to wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Condominium association board's claim against holding company was precluded by res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Boudreau v. Gentile
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil and hold an individual officer or shareholder liable for his corporation's conduct when (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual do not exist and (2) where the circumstances are such that an adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence promotes injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Companies constituted single enterprise were alter egos of shell company liable for unpaid contributions to union pension fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: GMAC, LLC v. Hillquist
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must satisfy a two prong test under Illinois law; first, the plaintiff must prove that there is a unity of interest and ownership such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual or other corporation no longer exist and, second, the plaintiff must show that circumstances exist such that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Sole proprietor was not liable for successor corporation's debts under theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Tyson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under American law, the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Bankruptcy court would pierce veil of shell corporation involved in international distribution of debtor's boxing match.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: In general, courts will disregard the corporate fiction, even though corporate formalities have been observed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Courts disregard the corporate fiction in tort cases in six general instances: (1) when the fiction is used as a means of perpetrating fraud; (2) where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another; (3) where the corporate fiction is resorted to as a means of evading an existing legal obligation; (4) where the corporate fiction is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; (5) where the corporate fiction is used to circumvent a statute; and (6) where the corporate fiction is relied upon as a protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Disregard of the corporate fiction is an equitable doctrine to which Texas takes a flexible fact-specific approach focusing on equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: "Alter ego," as basis for disregarding the corporate fiction, applies when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Similar equitable principles apply to both direct and reverse piercing of corporate veil, including principle that the veil will be pierced only when necessary to prevent an injustice and in exceptional circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re White
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Virginia, Roanoke Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, while proof of plain fraud is not a necessary element of veil-piercing claim, proof of some legal wrong is required.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Future promises of performance were not false representations for dischargeability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Labbe v. Carusone
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil requires proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must have proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Evidence did not establish fraudulent transfer after judgment against landlord.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Labbe v. Carusone
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under the identity rule for piercing the corporate veil, if the plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Evidence did not establish fraudulent transfer after judgment against landlord.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Daniels v. CDB Bell, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Kentucky jurisprudence recognizes three basic theories to pierce the corporate veil and hold the shareholders of a corporation responsible for corporate liabilities, and these the theories are (1) the instrumentality theory; (2) the alter ego theory; and (3) the equity formulation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether to pierce the corporate veil is an equitable question to be decided by the trial court and not the jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Siematic Mobelwerke GmbH & Co. KG v. Siematic Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, piercing the corporate veil is reserved for circumstances where equity demands that the corporate form be disregarded, such as to prevent fraud, illegality, or injustice, or when recognition of the corporate entity would defeat public policy or shield someone from liability for a crime; this is a stringent inquiry and courts deciding whether to disregard the corporate entity must start from the general rule that the corporate entity should be recognized and upheld, unless specific, unusual circumstances call for an exception.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Agreement between manufacturer and its distributor did not require the distributor to pay freight and installation charges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Siematic Mobelwerke GmbH & Co. KG v. Siematic Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The factors used to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil under Pennsylvania law are not exhaustive, nor is every element required for a finding of liability; however, the situation must present an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Agreement between manufacturer and its distributor did not require the distributor to pay freight and installation charges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Amaya v. Garden City Irrigation, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: As a general rule, New York law treats corporations as having an existence separate and distinct from that of their shareholders and consequently does not impose liability upon shareholders for the acts of the corporation; however, courts will disregard the separate legal personality of the corporation and assign liability to its owners where necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Limitations. Employees' failure to name defendant in original complaint was not the result of a mistake for relation back purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: McWilliams Ballard, Inc. v. Broadway Management Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, the corporate entity generally will be respected, but a party may be permitted to pierce the corporate veil upon proof that there is (1) unity of ownership and interest, and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong, or other considerations of justice and equity justify it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A developer stated a claim under District of Columbia law to pierce corporate veil of marketer of units in new development.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hill v. Kansas Dept. of Labor, Div. of Workers Compensation
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Kansas law recognizes two theories under which the corporate entity may be disregarded: (1) the alter ego theory and (2) the interest of justice theory.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Substantial competent evidence supported Workers' Compensation Division's factual findings that cab drivers were employees, rather than independent contractors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hill v. Kansas Dept. of Labor, Div. of Workers Compensation
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: The "alter ego doctrine," under which the corporate entity may be disregarded, imposes liability on an individual who uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct his or her own personal business, and such liability arises from fraud or injustice perpetrated not on the corporation but on third persons dealing with the corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Substantial competent evidence supported Workers' Compensation Division's factual findings that cab drivers were employees, rather than independent contractors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Smith v. Simmons
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, where corporation is used by individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, court may disregard corporate entity and treat corporation's acts as if they were done by persons actually controlling corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Buyer corporation's vice president did not personally guarantee its obligations under asset purchase agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Smith v. Simmons
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, to identify when individual is alter ego of corporate entity, there are two general requirements: (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and (2) that failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Buyer corporation's vice president did not personally guarantee its obligations under asset purchase agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Lewis v. Frazao Bldg. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality test for piercing the corporate veil requires proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Home improvement contract was ambiguous as to the scope of the work to be performed for $43,015 price.

Title: Utzler v. Braca
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: A court will disregard the corporate structure and pierce the corporate veil only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Builder fraudulently induced investor to provide funds to finance construction of new luxury home.

Title: Utzler v. Braca
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule to disregard a corporate entity requires proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Builder fraudulently induced investor to provide funds to finance construction of new luxury home.

Title: Gass v. Anna Hosp. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Under piercing-the-corporate-veil test, prong addressing whether circumstances exist so that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences requires an inquiry into whether there is an element of unfairness, something akin to fraud or deception, or the existence of a compelling public interest.

Title: Anthony v. Gator Cochran Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: The concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied in Georgia to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud, or evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Equity Trust Co. Custodian ex rel. Eisenmenger IRA v. Cole
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is an equitable remedy that may be applied in order to avoid an injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of entities involved in real estate fraud could be pierced under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Equity Trust Co. Custodian ex rel. Eisenmenger IRA v. Cole
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Proof of strict common law fraud is not required, in order to show that piercing corporate veil is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness, but evidence that the corporate entity has been operated as a constructive fraud or in an unjust manner must be presented.

Title: Needa Parts Mfg., Inc. v. PSNet, Inc.

Title: Needa Parts Mfg., Inc. v. PSNet, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Michigan courts will not pierce the corporate veil unless (1) the corporate entity was a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual; (2) the corporate entity was used to commit a fraud or wrong; and (3) the plaintiff suffered an unjust loss.

Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.

Headnote: Party need not demonstrate any actual fraud in order to pierce corporate veil under Delaware law; standard is whether corporation and other entity are operated as a single economic unit such that it would be inequitable for court to uphold legal distinction between them.

Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.

Headnote: Test applied by Delaware courts in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil is two-pronged: (1) whether entities in question operated as single economic entity; and (2) whether there was an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: In order to satisfy the second, or "unfairness," prong of two-pronged Delaware test for piercing corporate veil, plaintiff need not prove that corporation was created with fraud or unfairness in mind; it is sufficient to prove that it was so used.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Fraud or injustice, of kind required under Delaware law in order to pierce corporate veil, must consist of more than merely the tort or breach of contract which is basis of plaintiff's lawsuit; to hold that underlying cause of action could supply necessary fraud or injustice would render the second prong of test meaningless.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.

Title: Hamilton Beach Brands, Inc. v. Metric and Inch Tools, Inc.

Title: Hamilton Beach Brands, Inc. v. Metric and Inch Tools, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: In California, the alter ego doctrine does not guard every unsatisfied creditor of a corporation but instead affords protection where some conduct amounting to bad faith makes it inequitable for the corporate owner to hide behind the corporate form; difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy this standard.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Older corporation was not alter ego of younger corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hamilton Beach Brands, Inc. v. Metric and Inch Tools, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Two conditions generally are required for application of the alter ego doctrine in California to two related corporations: (1) such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate corporate personalities are merged, so that one corporation is a mere adjunct of another or the two companies form a single enterprise; and (2) an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of one corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Older corporation was not alter ego of younger corporation.

Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law governing corporate veil piercing claims, instrumentality rule requires proof of three elements: (1) complete domination of finances, policy, and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to such transaction had at that time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) use of such control by principal to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of proponent's legal rights, and (3) proximate causation of injury or unjust loss complained of as a result of such control and breach of duty.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Title: In re Two Springs Membership Club

Headnote: Elements required under Nevada law for court to find that individual is alter ego of corporation, each of which must be established by preponderance of evidence, are as follows: (1) that corporation is influenced and governed by alleged alter ego; (2) that there is such unity of interest and ownership between them that one is inseparable from other; and (3) that facts must be such that adherence to corporate fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Minno v. Pro-Fab, Inc.

Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
