Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Those seeking to pierce a corporate veil under New York law bear a heavy burden of showing that the corporation was dominated as to the transaction attacked and that such domination was the instrument of fraud or otherwise resulted in wrongful or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Green v. Ziegelman
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: For the corporate veil to be pierced, the corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another individual or entity, the corporate entity must have been used to commit a wrong or fraud, and there must have been an unjust injury or loss to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Circuit court in supplementary proceedings lacked authority to pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Trinity Health Sys. v. MDX Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Jefferson County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Trial court did not abuse discretion when it dismissed claim for misuse of partnership assets from declaratory judgment action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State Capital Title & Abstract Co. v. Pappas Business Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, in the absence of extraordinary circumstances, such as fraud or injustice, a court will generally decline to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic loss doctrine barred claim of contractor's breach of duty of loyalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State Capital Title & Abstract Co. v. Pappas Business Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, piercing the corporate veil is not a mechanism by which legal liability is imposed per se, but rather an equitable remedy designed to remedy a fundamental unfairness perpetrated under the guise of the corporate form.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic loss doctrine barred claim of contractor's breach of duty of loyalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State Capital Title & Abstract Co. v. Pappas Business Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: With respect to circumstances indicating that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, as element under New Jersey law for piercing the corporate veil, a plaintiff need not prove common law fraud but instead must demonstrate that the defendants, via the corporate form, perpetrated a fraud, injustice, or the like, which is a less exacting standard.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic loss doctrine barred claim of contractor's breach of duty of loyalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Miranco Contracting, Inc. v. Perel
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Equity will intervene to pierce the corporate veil and permit the assertion of claims against the individuals who control the corporation in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Co-owner of property could be held personally liable in quantum meruit action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Miranco Contracting, Inc. v. Perel
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that the individual defendants (1) exercised complete domination and control over the corporation, and (2) used such domination and control to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in injury.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Co-owner of property could be held personally liable in quantum meruit action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: RDM Holdings, LTD v. Continental Plastics Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: For the corporate veil to be pierced, the corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another individual or entity, the corporate entity must have been used to commit a wrong or fraud, and there must have been an unjust injury or loss to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Successor liability claim against corporation's alleged successor was not precluded on res judicata grounds by corporation's bankruptcy action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Christian v. Smith
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: A court will disregard a corporation's identity, or pierce the corporate veil, only where the corporation has been used to commit fraud, violate a legal duty, or perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the rights of another.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Oral agreement came within leading object exception to statute of frauds requirement that agreement to pay debt of another be in writing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Christian v. Smith
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must allege and prove that the corporation was under the actual control of the shareholder and that the shareholder exercised such control to commit a fraud or other wrong in contravention of the plaintiff's rights.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Oral agreement came within leading object exception to statute of frauds requirement that agreement to pay debt of another be in writing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Nassau County v. Richard Dattner Architect, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) the corporate owners exercised complete domination and control of the corporation in respect of the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination and control was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to hold parent liable for subsidiary's breach of contract

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Love v. Rebecca Development, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were sufficient to state claim against individual defendants under piercing corporate veil theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Love v. Rebecca Development, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the controlling corporation abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene; the concept is equitable in nature, and the decision whether to pierce the corporate veil in a given instance will depend on the facts and circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were sufficient to state claim against individual defendants under piercing corporate veil theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Telenor Mobile Communications AS v. Storm LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law permits veil-piercing where (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Contempt. Sanction of $100,000 per day, doubling every 30 days until shareholder complied with arbitration award, was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Muhs v. River Rats, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Brunswick Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, to establish liability under the alter ego doctrine, a plaintiff must demonstrate: (1) that the stockholders' disregard of the corporate entity made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs; (2) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist; and (3) to adhere to the doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Personal Injury. Seller of boat had an ownership interest at the time of the accident sufficient to hold him liable for negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: SSP Partners v. Gladstrong Investments (USA) Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Examples of when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result, so as to warrant disregard of corporate form to impose liability, are when the corporate structure has been abused to perpetrate a fraud, evade an existing obligation, achieve or perpetrate a monopoly, circumvent a statute, protect a crime, or justify wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations can not be held liable for each other's obligations merely because they are part of a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Loops, LLC v. Amercare Products, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Generally, a corporation is considered an entity separate and distinct from its officers or shareholders, but the court will disregard the corporate form when its recognition would aid in perpetuating a fraud or result in a manifest injustice.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Consumer Goods. Dismissing patent holder's claims against shareholders of manufacturers of counterfeit toothbrushes was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: AHA Sales, Inc. v. Creative Bath Products, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In general, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercise complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination is used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Sales representative stated cause of action against manufacturer under Labor Law statute regulating payment of commissions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Drury Development Corp. v. Foundation Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: A corporation will be looked upon as a legal entity until sufficient reason to the contrary appears; but when the notion of legal entity is used to protect fraud, justify wrong, or defeat public policy, the law will regard the corporation as an association of persons.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A judgment against a corporation is not a prerequisite to an alter ego claim.

Title: Drury Development Corp. v. Foundation Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: In applying the veil-piercing doctrine, the equities of both sides are to be considered, and each case must be decided on its own particular facts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. A judgment against a corporation is not a prerequisite to an alter ego claim.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must demonstrate: (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership between individual and corporation that separate personalities of corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) that circumstances are such that continued adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholders personally liable for margin debt.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in order to satisfy second prong of two-pronged test for piercing corporate veil, by showing that continued adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, plaintiff must point to more than the mere prospect of an unsatisfied judgment.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Jahelka

Headnote: Under South Dakota law, in order for court to pierce corporate veil, there must exist some nexus between shareholders' disregard of corporate fiction and the resulting injustice or inequity.

Title: Cantrell v. Putnam County Sheriff's Dep't
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil involves recovering from a shareholder rather than the corporation where the corporate form was so ignored, controlled or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of another and that the misuse of the corporate form would constitute a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Oko

Headnote: Under Maryland law, courts will pierce corporate veil only when necessary to prevent fraud or to enforce paramount equity.

Title: French-Tex Cleaners, Inc. v. Cafaro Co.

Title: Dombroski v. WellPoint, Inc.

Gasbarro, 2004 WL 583849.

Title: State ex rel. Cooper v. Ridgeway Brands Mfg., LLC
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Exceptions to the general rule of corporate insularity may be made when applying the corporate fiction would accomplish some fraudulent purpose, operate as a constructive fraud, or defeat some strong equitable claim; those who are responsible for the existence of the corporation are, in those situations, prevented from using its separate existence to accomplish an unconscionable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limitations. Addition of corporation's owner as defendant related back to State's filing of original complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State ex rel. Cooper v. Ridgeway Brands Mfg., LLC
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate form or "pierce the corporate veil" when necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limitations. Addition of corporation's owner as defendant related back to State's filing of original complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Alli v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, when the notion of a corporation as a legal entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify a wrong, protect fraud or defend a crime, that notion may be set aside and the corporation treated as being one with its shareholders.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Subsidized Housing. Termination of HAP contracts was justified by failure to provide decent, safe and sanitary housing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Charvat v. Farmers Ins. Columbus, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Insurance company could not be liable under Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991 (TCPA) for insurance sales telemarketing calls.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Freier
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, piercing the corporate veil depends on the shareholder's relationship to the corporation, and whether veil-piercing is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debt arising from debtor's failure to pay concrete supplier fell within fiduciary fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Freier
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, where a shareholder's relationship to the corporation demonstrates that the corporation is simply his alter ego, piercing the corporate veil will be a remedy if necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debt arising from debtor's failure to pay concrete supplier fell within fiduciary fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Freier
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, where it is demonstrated that a corporate entity has been operated as a constructive fraud or in an unjust manner, the corporate veil will be pierced to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debt arising from debtor's failure to pay concrete supplier fell within fiduciary fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Williamson v. Recovery Ltd. Partnership

Headnote: The general principle guiding courts in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is that liability is imposed when doing so would achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Contracts involving shipwreck recovery were all maritime, and thus subject to federal admiralty jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: NetJets Aviation, Inc. v. LHC Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to prevail under the alter-ego theory of piercing the veil, a plaintiff need not prove that there was actual fraud but must show a mingling of the operations of the entity and its owner plus an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Plaintiff's breach of contract claims were not duplicative of its claims for account stated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: NetJets Aviation, Inc. v. LHC Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil need not prove that the corporation was created with fraud or unfairness in mind; it is sufficient to prove that it was so used.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Plaintiff's breach of contract claims were not duplicative of its claims for account stated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Truck Ins. Exchange v. Palmer J. Swanson, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Requirements for application of alter ego doctrine, which must be established by a preponderance of the evidence, are: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Attorney Fees. Law firm, as nonsignatory to agreements, was not estopped from refusing to comply with arbitration clause in agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Baccash v. Sayegh
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil allows a corporation's separate legal existence to be disregarded to prevent fraud and achieve equity, the doctrine is typically employed by third parties seeking to circumvent the limited liability of the owners, and requires a showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward the plaintiff.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Malpractice. Plaintiff failed to establish prima facie case of legal malpractice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Restaurant Development Group, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, two requirements must be met in order for court to pierce corporate veil: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; and (2) circumstances must exist such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Trustee stated successor liability claim against corporate entity to which debtor's assets were transferred.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Maloney-Refaie v. Bridge at School, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: A court may disregard the corporate form in the interest of justice, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract, public wrong, or where equitable considerations among members of the corporation are involved.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Arbitration clause contained in employment agreement mandated arbitration of disputes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Richard A. Pulaski Const. Co., Inc. v. Air Frame Hangars, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Jersey.
Headnote: The limitations placed on a claimant's ability to reach behind a corporate structure are intentional, as the purpose of the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is to prevent an independent corporation from being used to defeat the ends of justice, to perpetrate fraud, to accomplish a crime, or otherwise to evade the law.
Document Preview: TORTS - Prima Facie Tort. Availability of contract claim against developer barred separate claim for prima facie tort against officer of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ketchem v. American Acceptance, Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Hammond Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, courts disregard the corporate fiction when the corporate form is so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it is merely the instrumentality of another and the misuse of the corporate form constitutes a fraud or promotes injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debtor stated claim under FDCPA for improperly seeking attorney fees for representation by related entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Connecticut Light and Power Co. v. Westview Carlton Group, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality test for piercing the corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to such transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Utility was not required to apply for appointment of rent receiver.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Red River Wings, Inc. v. Hoot, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: To apply the alter ego doctrine, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Majority limited partners breached fiduciary duties when they proceeded with planned takeover in a reckless manner.

Title: Sudden Service, Inc. v. Brockman Forklifts, Inc.

Headnote: A court may lift the corporate veil if it finds substantial reasons for doing so after weighing the following factors: (1) the amount of respect given to the separate entity of the corporation by its shareholders; (2) the degree of injustice visited on the litigants by recognition of the corporate entity; and (3) the fraudulent intent of the incorporators.

Title: N.L.R.B. v. Bolivar-Tees, Inc.

Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that a party would be unjustly enriched; a parent corporation that caused a subsidiary's liabilities and its inability to pay for them would escape those liabilities; or an intentional scheme to squirrel assets into a liability-free corporation while heaping liabilities upon an asset-free corporation would be successful.

Title: Postal Instant Press, Inc. v. Kaswa Corp.

Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the corporate form can be disregarded under the "alter ego" theory when a corporate entity has been so completely dominated that the corporate entity had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence, and has been so dominated in order to commit a fraud or wrong.

Title: In re Weldon Stump & Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporation is distinct legal entity, separate and apart from natural person(s) who compose it, and will not be disregarded in absence of fraud or manifest injustice, especially where corporate form has been observed.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Estate had no interest in proceeds of partnership between related corporate entity other than debtor and third parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Moore v. Moore
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Evidence supported determination that constructive trust arose by operation of law due to husband's financial misconduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Polo Builders, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Two elements must be met in order to pierce corporate veil under Illinois law: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; and (2) circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. LLC's veil could not be pierced to hold its members liable for LLC's breach of contract to purchase estate property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Polo Builders, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Second element for piercing of corporate veil under Illinois law, i.e., that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, can be satisfied by showing that use of corporation either (1) carries out a fraud by intentional wrongdoing or (2) promotes injustice, a lesser standard than fraud in that it does not require proof of fraudulent intent.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. LLC's veil could not be pierced to hold its members liable for LLC's breach of contract to purchase estate property.

Title: In re Polo Builders, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, separate corporate identities will be disregarded only if condition claimed to be unjust to corporate creditors is result of abuses of corporate form.

Title: GIW Industries, Inc. v. JerPeg Contracting, Inc.

Headnote: Under Georgia law, protection of the corporate veil cannot be afforded to a party who has over-extended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity to defeat justice, perpetrate fraud, or evade contractual or tort responsibility.

Title: TIP Systems, LLC v. SBC Operations, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: A court may exert its equitable powers and disregard the corporate entity if it decides that piercing the veil will prevent fraud, illegality, injustice, a contravention of public policy, or prevent the corporation from shielding someone from criminal liability.

Title: Pacer's Bar & Grill, Inc. v. Weinson's Inc.

Headnote: Broadly speaking, the courts will pierce the corporate veil whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Missouri courts will pierce the corporate veil and hold a defendant liable for the torts of another corporation under the instrumentality or alter ego rule if the plaintiff can establish (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and(3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Neuhauser

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Neuhauser
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under Illinois law must demonstrate that (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership between the individual and the corporation that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) the circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Neuhauser
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To satisfy fraud or injustice aspect of inquiry into whether piercing of the corporate veil is warranted, party requesting veil-piercing must point to more than the mere prospect of an unsatisfied judgment, and instead must show that some wrong beyond a creditor's inability to collect will result if veil is not pierced, such as the individuals sought to be held liable being unjustly enriched or unfairly avoiding liability after draining corporate assets.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Factual issues precluded summary judgment for debtor and transferees on constructive fraudulent transfer claim.

Title: Asperger v. Shop Vac Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in rare instances courts will disregard the corporate form to impose liability on shareholders and affiliated corporations if there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual or other corporation no longer exist and circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: T & R Trucking, Inc. v. Maynard
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in order to hold the shareholders actively participating in the operation of the business personally liable for breach to party who entered into the contract with the corporation, there is normally a two-prong test: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual shareholders no longer exist (a disregard of formalities requirement) and (2) an inequitable result would occur if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone (a fairness requirement).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Revocation of corporate license during contract term did not provide basis to hold president individually liable for breach.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Gann v. William Timblin Transit, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the following three elements must be present in order to pierce the corporate veil under the alter ego doctrine: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) defendant's use of control to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: In re Ma
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate form may be disregarded, and an individual shareholder may be held liable for corporate wrongs, when three requirements are met: (1) control over corporation by shareholder to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) control over corporation by shareholder to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit a fraud or illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted from such control and wrong to the person seeking to disregard corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the corporate fiction is disregarded, even though corporate formalities have been observed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result; specifically, the corporate fiction is disregarded (1) when the fiction is used as a means of perpetrating fraud, (2) where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, (3) where the corporate fiction is resorted to as a means of evading an existing legal obligation, (4) where the corporate fiction is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly, (5) where the corporate fiction is used to circumvent a statute, (6) where the corporate fiction is relied upon as a protection of crime or to justify wrong, and (7) in the case of inadequate capitalization.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor could pierce debtor-LLC's veil so as to hold nondebtor owners liable for default judgment.

Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC

Title: HOK Sport, Inc. v. FC Des Moines, L.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is a common-law equitable remedy whereby an entity's corporate form is disregarded to prevent an injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Person who was nonprofit's president and only officer and board member was liable for nonprofit's debts as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: HOK Sport, Inc. v. FC Des Moines, L.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, disregarding an entity's corporate form by piercing the corporate veil is appropriate if the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate business purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Person who was nonprofit's president and only officer and board member was liable for nonprofit's debts as alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bair v. Purcell
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania generally recognizes that corporate veil may be pierced whenever it is necessary to avoid injustice; however, there is strong presumption in Pennsylvania against piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Baking company owners did not deliberately misrepresent employment and business advancement opportunities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Milan v. Centennial Communications Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, the principal reasons that justify the piercing of a corporate veil are that the corporation is being used to sanction fraud, provide injustice, evade obligations, defeat public policy, justify inequity, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Employees who signed separation agreements knowingly and voluntarily waived all claims against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Four Seasons Mfg., Inc. v. 1001 Coliseum, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: As a general rule, Indiana courts are reluctant to disregard corporate identity and do so only to protect third parties from fraud or injustice when transacting business with a corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of LLC was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Teleglobe Communications Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Delaware courts respect entity separateness unless doing so would work inordinate inequity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Debtors' corporate parent could not unilaterally waive co-client privilege.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Vanderford Co., Inc. v. Knudson
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, March 2007 Term.
Headnote: In order for a corporation to be an alter ego of an individual, there must be: (1) a unity of interest and ownership to a degree that the separate personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, and (2) if the acts are treated as acts of the corporation an inequitable result would follow.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Deeds of trust on townhomes financed by construction loan did not serve as security for construction loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Courts are generally reluctant to disregard the corporate entity, and if any general rule can be laid down, it is that a corporation will be looked upon as a legal entity until sufficient reason to the contrary appears; but when the notion of legal entity is used to protect fraud, justify wrong, or defeat public policy, the law will regard the corporation as an association of persons.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Courts generally disregard the corporate entity only where equity requires piercing the corporate veil to assist a third party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: There is a two-prong test to determine whether a corporate veil should be pierced: the first part of the test requires an eight-factor analysis and looks to observance of the corporate formalities by the dominant shareholders, and the second part requires that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if the acts of the corporation be not regarded as the acts of the individuals.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: The essence of the fairness portion of the two-prong test to determine whether a corporate veil should be pierced is simply that an individual businessman cannot be allowed to hide from the normal consequences of carefree entrepreneuring by doing so through a corporate shell.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mid-South Mgt. Co. Inc. v. Sherwood Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: The main purpose of piercing the corporate veil is to prevent the likelihood of injustice or unfairness if the limited liability enjoyed by the corporate entity is sustained.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Partnership failed to prove sufficient number of Sturkie factors to justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil the plaintiff must satisfy a two-part test: (1) the plaintiff must show that there was such unity of interest and lack of respect given to the separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders that the personalities and assets of the corporation and the individual are indistinct, and (2) the plaintiff must show that adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: The alter ego test's second prong that adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations is addressed to the conscience of the court, and the circumstances under which it will be met will vary with each case.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: An element of unfairness, injustice, fraud, or other inequitable conduct is required as a prerequisite to piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: The mere fact that a corporation is incapable of paying all its debts is insufficient for a finding of injustice, as required to satisfy second prong of alter ego test, because that condition will exist in virtually all cases in which there is an attempt to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Title: Ventresca Realty Corp. v. Houlihan
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the law permits the incorporation of a business for the very purpose of escaping personal liability, equity will intervene to pierce the corporate veil and permit the imposition of personal liability in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted, so as to permit imposition of personal liability against corporation's principals.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Pae v. Chul Yoon
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Defendant owner of corporation which had contracted with plaintiff was personally liable under agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re B.L. Jennings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under California law, courts will ignore the corporate entity and deem corporation's acts to be those of persons or organizations actually controlling it, as corporation's alter egos, where corporate form is used to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose.

Title: In re B.L. Jennings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Generally, alter ego liability exists under California law when there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and of individual no longer exist, and when inequitable result will follow if acts are treated as those of corporation alone.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfer of unencumbered property for no consideration after debtor was named as tort defendant was fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re B.L. Jennings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Purpose of veil-piercing doctrine under California law is not to protect every unsatisfied creditor, but to afford him protection where some conduct amounting to bad faith makes it inequitable for equitable owner of corporation to hide behind its corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfer of unencumbered property for no consideration after debtor was named as tort defendant was fraudulent transfer.

Title: In re B.L. Jennings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under California law, party seeking to impose alter ego liability need not prove actual fraud, just that failure to impose alter ego liability will result in injustice.

Title: Davey v. Shaw
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: The alter ego theory is applicable only when the evidence shows that the two entities cease to be separate so that the corporate fiction should be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Jurisdiction. Alter ego theory could not be applied to confer personal jurisdiction over nonresident corporate and individual defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: California courts generally treat the alter ego doctrine as a drastic remedy and disregard the corporate form only reluctantly and cautiously; only when: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality, or separateness, of the said person and the corporation has ceased, and (2) an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice does California law recognize an alter ego relationship.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Damages. Award of lost profit damages to patent owner was not supported by substantial evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Comcast of IL X v. Multi-Vision Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine, as developed under corporate law, provides that the legal fiction of the separate corporate entity may be rejected in the case of a corporation that (1) is controlled by another to the extent that it has independent existence in form only and (2) is used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. Trust set up by judgment debtor was void and therefore did not protect assets from judgment creditor's claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mosaica Education, Inc. v. Pennsylvania Prevailing Wage Appeals Board
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The corporate form will be disregarded under the piercing the corporate veil doctrine only when the entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Labor and Employment. Charter school management company was not a contractor under the Charter School Law's Prevailing Wage Act requirements.

Title: Tzovolos v. Wiseman
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Justice required piercing corporate veils of corporate entities, including corporation and LLCs, of buyers of kitchen equipment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Tzovolos v. Wiseman
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Key factor in any decision to disregard the separate corporate entity and pierce the corporate veil is the element of control or influence exercised by the individual sought to be held liable over corporate affairs; court must avoid an overly-rigid preoccupation with questions of structure and apply the preexisting and overarching principle that liability is imposed to reach an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Justice required piercing corporate veils of corporate entities, including corporation and LLCs, of buyers of kitchen equipment.

Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, court may pierce corporate veil to prevent fraud, illegality, or injustice, or when recognition of corporate entity would defeat public policy or shield someone from liability for crime.

Title: In re National Audit Defense Network
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, three requirements must be satisfied in order for court to pierce corporate veil and to hold individual liable as alter ego of corporation: (1) corporation must be influenced and governed by person asserted to be its alter ego; (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other; and (3) facts must be such that adherence to fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice. West's NRSA 78.747.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfers pursuant to Ponzi-like scheme were made with actual fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re National Audit Defense Network
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Elements of reverse veil-piercing claim under Nevada law are: (1) that corporation must be influenced and governed by person asserted to be its alter ego; (2) that such unity of interest and ownership must exist between corporation and its alleged alter ego that one is inseparable from the other; and (3) that circumstances must be such that adherence to corporate fiction of separate entity would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfers pursuant to Ponzi-like scheme were made with actual fraudulent intent.

Title: Penn Nat. Gaming, Inc. v. Ratliff
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: The Supreme Court declines to pierce the corporate veil except in those extraordinary factual circumstances where to do otherwise would subvert the ends of justice.

Title: Butler v. Adoption Media, LLC

Headnote: Alter ego doctrine arises under California law when plaintiff comes into court claiming that opposing party is using corporate form unjustly and in derogation of plaintiff's interests.

Title: Graham v. Palmtop Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: In order to show that a corporation is a person's alter ego to justify disregarding the corporate entity, it must be shown that the stockholders' disregard of the corporate entity made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs, that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist, and that to adhere to the doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.

Title: Novak v. Scarborough Alliance Corp.

Headnote: Under New York law, piercing corporate veil is exceptional remedy requiring showing that: (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff that resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.

Title: Powell Company v. McGarey Group, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, a court may pierce the corporate veil if plaintiff can prove one of the following: (1) the shareholders disregarded the corporate entity, thereby making the entity a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs; (2) that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that there are no longer separate personalities of the corporation and the individuals; or (3) adherence to the doctrine of a corporate entity would promote injustice or perpetuate fraud.
