Title: Tower Investors, LLC v. 111 East Chestnut Consultants, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: The fraud or inequity that the alter ego doctrine aims to protect against must be that of the party against whom the doctrine is invoked and the party must have been an actor in the course of conduct constituting the abuse of corporate privilege.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES - Conflict of Interest. Investor, whose members came from law firm, did not breach forbearance agreement when firm brought action to collect fees.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts will pierce the corporate veil only if: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) circumstances are such that an adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation was not liable for judgment against subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re First Assured Warranty Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Hawai'i law, corporation will be deemed the alter-ego of another when recognition of corporate fiction would bring about injustice and inequity, or when there is evidence that corporate fiction has been used to perpetrate fraud or to defeat rightful claim.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Bankruptcy case did not have to be dismissed on McCarran-Ferguson Act grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re First Assured Warranty Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: In order for court to disregard corporate fiction under Hawai'i law and to treat corporation as alter ego of person, it must be made to appear: (1) that corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but that there is such unity of interest that the individuality, or separateness, of such person and corporation has ceased; and (2) that facts are such that adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would, under particular circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Bankruptcy case did not have to be dismissed on McCarran-Ferguson Act grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re First Assured Warranty Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, when deciding whether to disregard corporate fiction and to treat corporation and its shareholder as alter egos, court should determine whether justice requires recognizing the substance of relationship between the shareholder and corporation over the form, because corporate fiction was used to perpetrate fraud or to defeat rightful claim.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Bankruptcy case did not have to be dismissed on McCarran-Ferguson Act grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kalin v. Xanboo, Inc
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law allows corporate veil to be pierced where: (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Corporation's principals' alleged scheme to fraudulently induce employee could not be attributed to related company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Servo Kinetics, Inc. v. Tokyo Precision Instruments Co. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, courts will not pierce the corporate veil unless (1) the corporate entity was a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual; (2) the corporate entity was used to commit a fraud or wrong; and (3) the plaintiff suffered an unjust loss.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer's alleged breach of agreement was type of fraud or wrong that would support piercing parent's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ohio Bureau of Workers' Compensation v. MDL Active Duration Fund, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, a corporate form may be disregarded, and shareholders, officers and directors of the corporation may be held liable for corporate misdeeds when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control or wrong.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investor stated claim based on relationship and injury which was distinct from its status as shareholder in investment fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Fisher
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate veil may be pierced and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds, where it would be unjust to allow shareholder to hide behind fiction of corporate entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Court could pierce corporate veil to set aside sale of inventory of debtor's corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Adler, Coleman Clearing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To warrant piercing the corporate veil under New York law and thereby imposing liability on a person who effectively dominates or controls the vital affairs of a corporate entity, a plaintiff must establish that: (1) the owner exercised such control that the corporation has become a mere instrumentality of the owner, who is the real actor; (2) the owner used this control to commit a fraud or other wrong; and (3) the fraud or wrong results in an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Judgment. Control person could not challenge imposition of liability upon him for judgment entered by default against his alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Rohmer Associates, Inc. v. Rohmer
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: A corporation, even when wholly owned by a single individual, has a separate legal existence from its shareholders; however, a corporation's separate legal personality can, under limited circumstances, be disregarded when necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Judgment. Husband's release in divorce action of claims against wife also waived his corporation's claims against wife.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. All Meat and Poultry Products Stored at Lagrou Cold Storage
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, court may disregard corporate form of entities operating as alter egos of one another upon showing that: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporations and/or individuals no longer exist, and (2) circumstances are such that adhering to fiction of separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequity.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Food. Distribution companies stated contract claims stemming from alleged rodent infestation at storage facilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Valley X-Ray Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, corporation is alter ego of its owner if: (1) corporate entity is mere instrumentality of its owner; (2) corporate entity is used to commit fraud or wrong; and (3) there was unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Fraudulent transfer defendant was not entity for whose benefit transfer was made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Derivium Capital, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, concept that a corporation is an entity separate from its officers and shareholders is a legal fiction that the courts will disregard whenever recognition of the corporate form would produce injustices or inequitable consequences; courts may pierce the corporate veil and treat the corporation and its stockholders as identical in appropriate cases and in furtherance of the ends of justice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee's actual and constructive fraudulent transfer claims under South Carolina law did not satisfy fraud pleading rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Kilroy
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate when court must prevent fraud, illegality or injustice, or when recognition of corporate entity would defeat public policy or shield someone from liability for crime.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor was barred by prior judgment on alter ego claim from disputing that false statements should be attributed to him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Damianos Realty Group, LLC v. Fracchia
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Equity will intervene to pierce the corporate veil and permit the assertion of claims against the individuals who control the corporation, in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff failed to make prima facie showing in support of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Damianos Realty Group, LLC v. Fracchia
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that the individual defendants (1) exercised complete dominion and control over the corporation, and (2) used such dominion and control to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff failed to make prima facie showing in support of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Meredith
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, party seeking to disregard the corporate entity must show that the shareholder sought to be held personally liable has controlled or used the corporation to evade a personal obligation, to perpetrate fraud or a crime, to commit an injustice, or to gain an unfair advantage, and a court ruling which pierces the corporate veil, and which subjects an individual shareholder to personal liability for corporate obligations, is only justified when the unity of interest and ownership is such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfers of assets of Chapter 7 debtor were made with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Teknek, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Illinois law, there must be both: (1) such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of person and corporation no longer exist; and (2) circumstances under which adherence to fiction of corporate separateness would promote injustice or inequity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Jurisdiction. Debtor-LLC's contacts could be counted as contacts of its members in order to establish personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: d'Elia v. Rice Development, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Two circumstances must exist to disregard the corporate entity under the equitable alter ego doctrine: (1) such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, but the corporation is, instead, the alter ego of one or a few individuals, and (2) if observed, the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or result in an inequity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. The owner of a limited liability company was personally liable for tortious acts of the company in which he participated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: d'Elia v. Rice Development, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Under the "fairness requirement" prong of the alter ego doctrine that considers whether observing the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or result in an inequity, its satisfaction is left to the conscience of the court.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. The owner of a limited liability company was personally liable for tortious acts of the company in which he participated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Weddle
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, courts may disregard the corporate entity if two conditions are met: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and the individual that their separate personalities no longer exist; and (2) failing to treat acts of corporation as those of the individual will lead to an inequitable result, sanctioning a fraud or promoting injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Judgment creditor was not insider at time of alleged preference.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Scott v. NG U.S. 1, Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: The doctrine of corporate disregard is an equitable tool that authorizes courts, in rare situations, to ignore corporate formalities, where such disregard is necessary to provide a meaningful remedy for injuries and to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Hazardous Substances. Whether power company was responsible for utility's environmental responsibilities precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Alstom SA
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In New York, to pierce the corporate veil, plaintiffs must generally show two things: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investors sufficiently stated veil-piercing theory of liability against corporate parent on control person claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Camofi Master LDC v. College Partnership, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts will only pierce corporate veil where there has been complete control by dominating party that leads to wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Commercial Paper. Financial advisor's purported fraudulent inducement could not serve as defense in action to collect sums due under notes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego remedy applies when there is such an identity or unity between a corporation and an individual or other entity that all separateness between the parties has ceased and a failure to disregard the corporate form would be unfair or unjust.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Settlements. Approval of proposed settlement was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Roiser v. Cascade Mountain, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: The remedy of disregarding or piercing the corporate veil in order to get to assets held by an individual will be employed where there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and where adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Wisconsin snowboard facility operators' contacts with Illinois were insufficient to confer general jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, piercing of corporate veil requires that: (1) there be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual, or other corporation, no longer exist, and (2) circumstances be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Laborers' Pension Fund v. Lay-Com, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, party seeking to show "sanctioning fraud" or "promoting injustice" prong of test for piercing corporate veil need not demonstrate fraud or intent to injure creditors, but must show something more than mere prospect of unsatisfied judgment, e.g. some element of unfairness or existence of compelling public interest.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Company was successor to dissolved entity, and bound by its union agreements, given identity of successor's operations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Baize v. Eastridge Companies, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: The "alter ego doctrine" arises when a plaintiff claims that an opposing party is using the corporate form unjustly and in derogation of the plaintiff's interests; as the separate personality of the corporation is a statutory privilege, it must be used for legitimate business purposes and must not be perverted, and when it is abused it will be disregarded and the corporation looked at as a collection or association of individuals, so that the corporation will be liable for acts of the stockholders or the stockholders liable for acts done in the name of the corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Alternative Dispute Resolution. Arbitration award was not reviewable for errors of law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Baize v. Eastridge Companies, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: There is no litmus test to determine when the corporate veil will be pierced under the alter ego doctrine, as the result will depend on the circumstances of each particular case; there are two general requirements: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Alternative Dispute Resolution. Arbitration award was not reviewable for errors of law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Old Farms Associates v. Commissioner of Revenue Services
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is equitable in nature.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Real Property. Land seller could not be assessed conveyance tax on consideration paid by buyer to builder for the construction of a house.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sofi Classic S.A. de C.V. v. Hurowitz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Standard for piercing corporate veil under South Carolina law requires that there be element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if acts of corporation are not regarded as acts of shareholders.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mexican garment manufacturer stated claim for piercing corporate veil against officers of import company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sofi Classic S.A. de C.V. v. Hurowitz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To prove fundamental unfairness, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under South Carolina law, plaintiff must establish that: (1) defendant was aware of plaintiff's claim against corporation, and (2) thereafter, defendant acted in self-serving manner with regard to property of corporation and in disregard of plaintiff's claim in property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mexican garment manufacturer stated claim for piercing corporate veil against officers of import company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Verni ex rel. Burstein v. Harry M. Stevens, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: In the absence of fraud or injustice, courts generally will not pierce the corporate veil to impose liability on the corporate principals.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Irrelevant evidence was admitted in beverage server liability action against stadium's concessions contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Bianchini
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, piercing the corporate, or entity, veil is governed by equitable principles.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor could not reverse pierce entity veil in order to avoid lien on exemption-impairment grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Prymas v. Kassai
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Generally, an individual officer or shareholder will not be held liable for the acts or debts of a corporation; an exception to this rule applies in cases when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Trial. Refusal to instruct the jury on an easement by estoppel defense to a trespass claim was an abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Advanced Const. Corp. v. Pilecki
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: The corporate veil can be pierced when the party seeking to do so establishes that the other party abused the privilege of a separate corporate identity and an unjust or inequitable result would occur if the court recognized the separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Evidence established that shareholder of home builder participated in wrongful acts and was personally liable to homeowners.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Turner
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, only two things must be established to support liability on alter ego theory: (1) a unity of interest and ownership, such that the person and the entity cannot fairly be considered separate; and (2) injustice resulting from court's adherence to fiction that entity and individual have a separate existence.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor did not have to formally be identified as owner for court to rely on alter ego theory to avoid transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Phillips
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: Traditional piercing of the corporate veil penetrates the corporate veil and imposes liability on individual shareholders for the obligations of the corporation; individual liability is appropriate when the corporation is merely the alter ego of the shareholder, and the corporate structure is used to perpetuate a wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Colorado Supreme Court rules that Colorado law permits outside reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Phillips
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: To determine whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, the court must: (1) inquire into whether the corporate entity is the alter ego of the shareholder; (2) inquire whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the shareholder and corporation over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim; and (3) evaluate whether an equitable result will be achieved by disregarding the corporate form and holding the shareholder personally liable for the acts of the business entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Colorado Supreme Court rules that Colorado law permits outside reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Phillips
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: Achieving an equitable result is the paramount goal of traditional piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Colorado Supreme Court rules that Colorado law permits outside reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Phillips
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado, En Banc.
Headnote: A court may reverse pierce the corporate veil and obtain the assets of a corporation for the obligations of a controlling shareholder or other corporate insider only upon a clear showing that (1) the controlling insider and the corporation are alter egos of each other, (2) justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship over the form because the corporate fiction is utilized to perpetuate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim, and (3) an equitable result is achieved by piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Colorado Supreme Court rules that Colorado law permits outside reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Verestar, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors establishing that the entities acted as a single economic unit for purposes of claim for alter ego liability under Delaware law include whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder; some combination of factors is required, and an overall element of injustice or unfairness must always be present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Committee stated claims for constructive fraudulent transfers, but not actual fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State ex rel. Petro v. Mercomp, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: A fundamental rule of corporate law is that, normally, shareholders, officers, and directors are not liable for the debts of the corporation; however, the "veil" of the corporation can be "pierced" and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when it would be unjust to allow the shareholders to hide behind the fiction of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold sole shareholder liable for corporation's violations of solid waste regulations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Hansen
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, in order for court to ignore corporation's separate existence and treat it as alter ego of its shareholder, there must be both: (1) such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of shareholder and corporation no longer exist; and (2) circumstances under which adherence to fiction of corporate separateness would promote injustice or inequity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Status as majority shareholder in corporate transferee did not make individual liable on avoided transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Western Reserve Life Assur. Co. of Ohio v. Bratton
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Cedar Rapids Division.
Headnote: Under Iowa law, a court may disregard a corporate structure by piercing the corporate veil only under circumstances where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate business purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Verbal agreement had not been integrated and merged into subsequent written agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Anderson v. Stewart
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is founded in equity and is applied when the facts warrant its application to prevent an injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Trial court could pierce corporate veil of payday lender and hold current and former members personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Television Events & Marketing, Inc. v. AMCON Distributing, Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Hawai'i.
Headnote: In Hawaii, a corporation may be the alter ego of another where recognition of the corporate fiction would bring about injustice and inequity or when there is evidence that the corporate fiction has been used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Licenses. Genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether best efforts provisions of license agreements were breached.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine applies only if (1) the owner exercised complete control over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such control was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Government of Turkmenistan could be liable for arbitration award as alter ego of its wholly-owned oil company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Fraud is not the only type of injustice that satisfies the second prong of the alter ego test; rather, the prong has a broader scope that includes the misuse of the corporate form to promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Government of Turkmenistan could be liable for arbitration award as alter ego of its wholly-owned oil company.

Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a court may pierce the corporate veil where 1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and 2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.

Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, broadly speaking, the courts will disregard the corporate form, or, to use accepted terminology, pierce the corporate veil, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, because disregarding corporate separateness as an equitable remedy is one that differs with the circumstances of each case, no single factor or even combination of factors is dispositive; the general principle followed by the courts has been that liability is imposed when doing so would achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Title: Ventresca Realty Corp. v. Houlihan
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the law permits the incorporation of a business for the very purpose of escaping personal liability, equity will intervene to pierce the corporate veil and permit the imposition of personal liability in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff stated breach of contract claim against individual defendants pursuant to piercing corporate veil theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sharper Image Corp. v. Target Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, court may pierce the corporate veil only where: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality, or separateness, of the said person and corporation has ceased, and (2) an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Privileges. California litigation privilege applied to counterclaims for non-infringement of patents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dearth v. Collins
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, to establish the alter ego doctrine permitting piercing of corporate veil, it must be shown [1] that the stockholders' disregard of the corporate entity made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs; [2] that there was such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist; and [3] to adhere to the doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Relief under Title VII was not available against employer's sole shareholder/president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mayes v. Moore
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: A court can disregard the corporate form and impose liability on a shareholder, or pierce the veil of protection, under the alter-ego theory when (1) the shareholder dominates and controls the organization and (2) imposing such liability is needed to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, as required to state claim against shareholder under Title VII.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mayes v. Moore
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Injustice, as required to pierce the corporate veil, can include a finding that the shareholder committed fraud, but fraud is not required.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, as required to state claim against shareholder under Title VII.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mayes v. Moore
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Decisions to pierce a corporate veil must be taken reluctantly and cautiously, but courts will not hesitate to take such action when justice so requires.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, as required to state claim against shareholder under Title VII.

Title: In re Garden Ridge Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Purpose of disregarding corporate entity under Texas law is to prevent fraud, illegality, or to avoid an otherwise inequitable result.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Former employee of one debtor could not engage in triangular setoff involving his obligations on note held by another debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: East Market Street Square, Inc. v. Tycorp Pizza IV, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate form or "pierce the corporate veil," and extend liability for corporate obligations beyond the confines of a corporation's separate entity, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.

Title: Heim v. Tri-Lakes Ford Mercury, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Whether to pierce the corporate veil is a fact-based determination which generally requires a showing that the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction or matter at issue and used that control to perpetrate a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which led to the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted concerning corporation that owned plane.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ross v. Auto Club Group
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: A corporation's separate existence will be respected, unless doing so would subvert justice or cause a result that would be contrary to some other clearly overriding public policy.

Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Liability imposed after piercing the corporate veil arises from fraud or injustice perpetrated not on the corporation but on third persons dealing with the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: A two-prong test is employed in order to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) circumstances must exist such that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Fontana v. TLD Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Actual fraud is not necessarily a predicate to piercing the corporate veil; limited liability may be discarded to prevent injustice or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of the corporate veil of construction company to hold president liable was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hoffmann v. Dandurand
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Examples of where corporate form has been used to achieve unequitable result, as will support application of alter ego theory to disregard corporate fiction that corporation is separate legal entity that insulates its owners or shareholders from personal liability, include: (1) where corporate fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud; (2) where corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; (3) where corporate fiction is resorted to as means of evading existing legal obligation; (4) where corporate fiction is used to achieve or perpetrate monopoly; (5) where corporate fiction is used to circumvent statute; or (6) where corporate fiction is relied on as protection of crime or to justify wrongdoing. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have special jurisdiction over nonresident chief executive officer of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Adler, Coleman Clearing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To warrant piercing the corporate veil under New York law and thereby imposing liability on a person who effectively dominates or controls the vital affairs of a corporate entity, a plaintiff must establish that: (1) the owner exercised such control that the corporation has become a mere instrumentality of the owner, who is the real actor; (2) the owner used this control to commit a fraud or other wrong; and (3) the fraud or wrong results in an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual had sufficient control over companies to warrant piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Rasheed v. Klopp Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: To justify piercing the corporate veil to hold a corporate owner liable, it must be shown that the stockholders' disregard of the corporate entity made it a mere instrumentality for the transaction of their own affairs, that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist, and that to adhere to the doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud; such evidence may include the owner using corporate funds for personal expenses or the owner bleeding one company to pay the expenses of another company he owns or the owner treating all his companies and himself as one unit.
Document Preview: TORTS - Pleading. Motorist's proposed amendment to personal injury complaint satisfied requirements for relation back to original filing date.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Beck v. Consolidated Rail Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the party who seeks to pierce the corporate veil of a parent company must make a two-part showing: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Former owner of property owed no direct duty to pedestrian injured when curb broke under her foot.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Kreisler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, a corporate entity will be disregarded, and its veil of limited liability pierced, when two requirements are met: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and individual no longer exist, and (2) adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote an injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Court declined to pierce claimant's corporate veil, and so its purchase of mortgage and notes did not extinguish its claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Kreisler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, once the "mere instrumentality" prong of the test for piercing the corporate veil has been satisfied, either the sanctioning of a fraud or the promotion of injustice will satisfy the second prong of the test.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Court declined to pierce claimant's corporate veil, and so its purchase of mortgage and notes did not extinguish its claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Lindell
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: To determine whether shareholder can be liable for corporate obligations on veil-piercing theory under Minnesota law, courts first consider shareholder's actions with regard to corporation based on factors such as shareholder's failure to observe corporate formalities, absence of corporate records, and whether corporation is merely facade for individual dealings, and then decide whether veil-piercing is necessary in order to prevent injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtors did not receive reasonably equivalent value for promissory note.

Title: In re Lindell
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: To prove that veil-piercing is necessary to prevent injustice or fundamental unfairness, as required under Minnesota law to hold shareholder liable for corporate debt, it is sufficient for plaintiff to show that corporation has been operated as a constructive fraud or in unjust manner.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtors did not receive reasonably equivalent value for promissory note.

Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Ohio law allows the corporate veil to be pierced and individual shareholders or directors held liable when it would be unjust to allow the shareholders to hide behind the fiction of the corporate entity.

Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, piercing the corporate veil is an equitable remedy, available not where a set list of factors are established but where maintaining the corporate form would work injustice upon an innocent party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Morris v. Cee Dee, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rules for piercing the corporate veil require, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of LLC's veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. Greer
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Asheville Division.
Headnote: North Carolina law requires that for corporate form to be disregarded following elements must be shown: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of.
