Title: F. Hoffman-La Roche, Ltd. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Sixth District, California.
Headnote: To invoke alter ego doctrine in corporate law, two conditions must be met: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership between corporation and its equitable owner that separate personalities of corporation and shareholder do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be inequitable result if acts in question are treated as those of corporation alone.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Swiss corporations were not subject to personal jurisdiction in state under representative services doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Bridge Information Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: General rule under Missouri law is that court should pierce corporate veil only upon a showing by third party that it has been injured by abuse of corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Fraud claim was one for direct injury to debtor-corporation and included in bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kantor v. Mesibov
Court: Supreme Court, Nassau County, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in that plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Business judgment rule did not protect conduct of managing partner from breach of fiduciary duty claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: EED Holdings v. Palmer Johnson Acquisition Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must generally show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations did not state claim against owner of holding company for piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dickens v. Alliance Analytical Laboratories, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3, Special Panel.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, two separate, essential factors must be established; first, the corporate form must be intentionally used to violate or evade a duty and, second, the fact finder must establish that disregarding the corporate veil is necessary and required to prevent an unjustified loss to the injured party.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Issue of fact existed as to whether individual was personally liable as agent for unpaid wages, through corporate piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Maroun v. Wyreless Systems, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2005 Term.
Headnote: To warrant casting aside the legal fiction of distinct corporate existence, it must be shown that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality of such corporation and such person has ceased, and it must further appear from the facts that the observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Employer's representations were not actionable as fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Maroun v. Wyreless Systems, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2005 Term.
Headnote: Evidence that the job plaintiff employee left, to join corporate employer's start-up business, was a good job was not relevant to the injustice element of plaintiff's claim to pierce the corporate veil; injustice element of alter ego claim related towhether plaintiff might have a judgment against corporation and be unable to collect on that judgment because of financial situation of corporation and informality of corporate structure.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Employer's representations were not actionable as fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: In an appropriate case and in furtherance of the ends of justice, the separate identity of a corporation may be discarded and the individual or individuals owning all its stock and assets will be treated as identical to the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Boles v. National Development Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporation as a separate entity upon a showing that the corporation is a sham or dummy or such action is necessary to accomplish justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of corporate developer that breach contract to build lake in recreational development was alter ego of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Baillie Lumber Co. v. Thompson
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: The concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied to remedy injustices which arise where a party has overextended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud, or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation may bring action against principal of corporation to recover on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: SR Inter. Business Ins. Co., Ltd. v. World Trade Center Properties, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: No showing of fraud is required under Delaware law to pierce the corporate veil of an entity on an alter ego theory; rather, the injustice or unfairness must arise from the defendant's use of the corporate form, and may include factors such as contravention of law or contract, public wrong, or equitable considerations.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Property. Post-loss assignment of retail lessee's rental insurance claim was valid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Aoki
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the First Circuit.
Headnote: In Massachusetts, corporations and their shareholders are generally deemed to be distinct legal entities; however, under unusual circumstances, a court may disregard the corporate form, particularly to defeat fraud or remedy an injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced where principals siphoned money from corporation and used corporation to perpetrate frauds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Aspex Eyewear, Inc. v. Altair Eyewear, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: A court may disregard the corporate entity if it decides that piercing the veil will prevent fraud, illegality, injustice, a contravention of public policy, or prevent the corporation from shielding someone from criminal liability.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Parties. Absent any basis to pierce the corporate veil, principal would not be added as defendant in infringement suit against subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Summers
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: General principle of Michigan law is that separate corporate identities will be respected, and that corporate veils will be pierced only to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Numerous errors on schedules warrant inference of fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Summers
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, court may find that one entity is alter ego of another and pierce corporate veil upon proof of three elements: (1) that corporate entity is mere instrumentality of another; (2) that corporate entity was used to commit fraud or wrong; and (3) that there was an unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Numerous errors on schedules warrant inference of fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Shuck v. Wichita Hockey, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under federal common law, veil of corporation may be pierced if evidence establishes: (1) such unity of interest and lack of respect given to separate identity of corporation by its shareholders that personalities and assets of corporation and individual are indistinct, and (2) that adherence to corporate fiction would sanction fraud, promote injustice, or lead to evasion of legal obligations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold employer's owner personally liable under COBRA absent alter ego evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State v. Weinschenk
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Although corporations are separate legal entities with limited liability, courts may disregard the corporate entity when entity is used to cover fraud or illegality or to justify a wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Indirect purchasers of defective houses were not entitled to restitution in state's action under Unfair Trade Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State v. Weinschenk
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Court may pierce the corporate veil if a plaintiff establishes that: (1) the defendant abused the privilege of a separate corporate identity, and (2) an unjust or inequitable result would occur if the court recognized the separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Indirect purchasers of defective houses were not entitled to restitution in state's action under Unfair Trade Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Goff ex rel. Estate of Torango v. Harrah's Operating Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a party must prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the financial structure of the suspect corporation is only a sham and that it caused an injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unjust Enrichment. Plaintiff did not establish claim for unjust enrichment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Perry v. Unum Life Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, upon equitable principles the legal entity of a corporation may be disregarded; however, great caution should be exercised by the court in doing so, and there must be evidence of abuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Disability. Parent of disability insurer was not liable for tortious interference with insurance contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Enterprise Acquisition Partners, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: There are two general requirements for application of alter ego doctrine under California law: (1) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) that, if acts are treated as acts of corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Corporation wholly owned by statutory insider was not statutory insider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Enterprise Acquisition Partners, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, piercing the corporate veil requires more than unity of interest between corporation and its shareholder; it also requires some inequity arising out of use of corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Corporation wholly owned by statutory insider was not statutory insider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Katzir's Floor and Home Design, Inc. v. M-MLS.com
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: The injustice that allows a corporate veil to be pierced under California law is not a general notion of injustice; rather, it is the injustice that results only when corporate separateness is illusory.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Due process was violated by adding principal as judgment debtor through amendment of judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Escobedo v. BHM Health Associates, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil may only recover from a shareholder if the party proves by a preponderance of the evidence that the corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of another and that the misuse of the corporate form would constitute a fraud or promote injustice. West's A.I.C. 23-1-26-3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose liability on shareholders unpaid wages was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Moses v. Martin
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must prove that: (1) the owner exercised such control that the corporation has become a mere instrumentality of the owner, who is the real actor; (2) the owner used this control to commit a fraud or other wrong; and (3) the fraud or wrong results in an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. A managing agency could not be held vicariously liable under RICO for acts of its principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Giampietro
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under the test set forth in the Nevada Supreme Court's McCleary Cattle Co. decision and subsequently codified in essence, there are three requirements for ignoring the separate existence of a corporation pursuant to the alter ego doctrine: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice. West's NRSA 78.747.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Plaintiff was not a creditor of debtor and so lacked standing to file § 727(a)(3) complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Giampietro
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, in establishing the third prong of the McCleary Cattle Co. test for alter ego liability, it is not necessary that plaintiff prove actual fraud; rather, it is enough if the recognition of the two entities as separate would result in an injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Plaintiff was not a creditor of debtor and so lacked standing to file § 727(a)(3) complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Giampietro
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Simply not being paid is not, in and of itself, sufficient "injustice" to invoke alter ego liability under Nevada law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Plaintiff was not a creditor of debtor and so lacked standing to file § 727(a)(3) complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: EED Holdings v. Palmer Johnson Acquisition Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must generally show that: (1) owners exercised complete domination over corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Yacht buyer failed to state corporate veil-piercing claim as to boat builder's officer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Insituform Technologies, Inc. v. CAT Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded if doing so will prevent fraud, illegality, injustice, contravention of public policy, or prevent corporation from shielding someone from criminal liability.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Damages. Court should have held hearing to resolve fact dispute related to damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re White
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: Under Nebraska law, corporate veil may be pierced to hold shareholder liable, when shareholder has used corporation to commit fraud, to violate a legal duty, or to perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of rights of another.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. State court judgment was entitled to preclusive effect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: National Plan Administrators, Inc. v. National Health Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Courts are willing to disregard the corporate form when it is used as part of an unfair device to achieve an inequitable result, such as when a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, or when the corporate fiction is resorted to as a means of evading an existing legal obligation.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Third-party administrator and parent corporation were liable to health insurer for breach of fiduciary duty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wood v. McDonald's Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate form or pierce the corporate veil, and extend liability for corporate obligations beyond the confines of a corporation's separate entity whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support piercing corporate veil of assignee of restaurant franchise and management company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mandeville v. Quinstar Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Kansas law, former employee had to show that corporation's sole shareholder used corporation to conduct his own business, and that adherence to corporate fiction would result in injustice.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Sanctions. District court did not abuse its discretion in failing to dismiss action as sanction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Taylor v. Clark
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Evidence established that transfers from former husband's corporation to his new wife were not fraudulent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sunbelt Environmental Services, Inc. v. Rieder's Jiffy Market, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control was used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil to impose liability on trustee, store, and transferee corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Perfect 10, Inc. v. CCBill, LLC
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Elements of alter ego theory of liability are that (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of two entities no longer exist and (2) failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Internet. ISP came within DMCA safe harbor for providers who merely link users to infringing websites.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Cambridge Electronics Corp. v. MGA Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: The "alter ego doctrine" arises when plaintiff comes into court claiming that an opposing party is using the corporate form unjustly and in derogation of plaintiff's interests; in certain circumstances, court will disregard the corporate entity and will hold the individual shareholders liable for the actions of the corporation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Payment made by corporation to shareholder's father was not fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Cambridge Electronics Corp. v. MGA Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Purpose of the alter ego doctrine is to bypass the corporate entity to avoid injustice, and its essence is that justice be done, and therefore corporate form will be disregarded only in narrowly defined circumstances and only when the ends of justice so require.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Payment made by corporation to shareholder's father was not fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Cambridge Electronics Corp. v. MGA Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Two elements must be established before alter ego doctrine may be invoked: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) that an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Payment made by corporation to shareholder's father was not fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Delcastillo v. Odyssey Resource Management, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: Legal fiction of separate corporate entity may be rejected in case of corporation that (1) is controlled by another to extent that it has independent existence in form only and (2) is used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate fraud.

Title: In re Ticketplanet.com
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, no single factor justifies decision to disregard entity's corporate form; rather some combination of factors is required, and an overall element of injustice or unfairness must always be present.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Ticketplanet.com
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To support a veil-piercing claim under Delaware law, there must be an abuse of corporate form to effect some fraud or injustice, i.e., some sort of elaborate shell game.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Secured Transactions. Problems with post-default foreclosure sale did not cause it to be a conversion.

Title: Rymal v. Baergen

Headnote: For corporate veil to be pierced, corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another individual or entity, corporate entity must have been used to commit a wrong or fraud, and there must have been an unjust injury or loss to plaintiff.

Title: In re Devos, Inc.

Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, corporate veil may be pierced whenever necessary to avoid injustice.

Title: Washington Water Jet Workers Ass'n v. Yarbrough
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and impose liability on owners, plaintiff must demonstrate that the corporate form was used to violate or evade a duty, and that it must be disregarded to prevent loss to an innocent party.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Contract between state and private business to employ prisoners was unconstitutional.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Strawbridge v. Sugar Mountain Resort, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Asheville Division.
Headnote: In North Carolina, courts apply the "instrumentality rule," disregarding the corporate entity and imposing liability upon a dominant shareholder where the plaintiff can prove the following three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Gangwish v. Gangwish
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Ordinarily, a corporation is regarded as a separate entity, distinct from the members who compose it, but equity allows a court to disregard the corporate veil when necessary to do justice.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Child Support. Court was within its discretion to look to corporation to determine husband's income for child support purposes.

Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded only where equity requires the action to assist a third party.

Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Generally, a corporation will be looked upon as a legal entity until sufficient reason to the contrary appears; but when the notion of legal entity is used to protect fraud, justify wrong, or defeat public policy, the law will regard the corporation as an association of persons.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Dominant shareholder was responsible for judgment against corporation under alter ego theory.

Title: New England Homes, Inc. v. R.J. Guarnaccia Irrevocable Trust
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: When courts pierce the corporate veil, they assess individual liability where the owners have used the corporate identity to promote injustice or fraud.

Title: In re Casini

Title: Flynn v. Thibodeaux Masonry, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To determine if piercing the corporate veil is warranted, the court applies a two-prong test, asking: (1) whether there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) whether, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder was personally liable for corporation's ERISA liability upon corporate veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Exter Shipping Ltd. v. Kilakos
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: No uniform standard exists under federal common law for determining when a corporation is the alter ego of its owners; each case must be decided based upon the totality of the circumstances, considering factors including (1) commingling of corporate and personal finances, (2) failure to hold director/shareholder meetings or maintain corporate records, (3) non-functioning of other officers/directors, and (4) whether failure to disregard the corporate fiction would be unjust or fundamentally unfair to an injured party.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over Greek owners of time charterer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bowoto v. Chevron Texaco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Courts disregard the corporate form in some instances where such disregard is necessary to prevent injustice to a person or entity that would be harmed by refusing to impose liability on the basis of the corporate structure.

Title: In re Flutie New York Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff must demonstrate: (1) that the owner has exercised such control that corporation has become a mere instrumentality of owner; (2) that such control has been used to commit fraud or other wrong; and (3) that this fraud or wrong results in unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.

Headnote: New York courts will find liability on veil piercing theory when doing so would achieve an equitable result.

Title: In re Flutie New York Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to assert claim for individual liability upon alter ego theory, one must plead two elements: (1) that person exercises such complete domination and control with respect to the transaction attacked that corporation had, at the time, no separate will of its own; and (2) that this domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which caused plaintiff's injury.

Headnote: Corporations are separate legal entities, and Maine courts are generally reluctant to disregard legal entity and will cautiously do so only when necessary to promote justice.

Title: In re Crowe Rope Industries, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maine.
Headnote: Under Maine law, before court may pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must establish: (1) that defendant abused privilege of separate corporate identity; and (2) that unjust or inequitable result will occur if court recognizes corporation's separate existence.

Title: Richmond v. Indalex Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, elements warranting piercing the corporate veil under mere instrumentality rule are (1) control not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, (2) use of such control by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, and (3) proximate causation of injury or unjust loss complained of by that control and breach of duty.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent companies' alleged control of an employer would not permit piercing corporate veil for employee's injury.

Title: Taverns for Tots, Inc. v. City of Toledo
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form may be disregarded when urged to intent and purpose not within its reason and policy, and individual shareholders may be held liable for corporate misdeeds when it would be unjust to allow the shareholders to hide behind fiction of corporate entity.

Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California, Western Division.
Headnote: In order for acts of corporation to be legally recognized as being controlled by individual person, California law requires that: (1) corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but that there is such unity of interest and ownership that individuality, or separateness, of said person and corporation has ceased, and (2) facts are such that adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would, under particular circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Personal Liability. Sole shareholder was not personally liable for company's patent infringement.

Title: Fanning v. Brown

Headnote: Courts may disregard the corporate entity and hold stockholders personally liable for corporate obligations or corporate conduct under the legal doctrines of fraud, alter ego and when necessary to protect the rights of third persons and accomplish justice.

Title: Harte-Hanks Direct Marketing/Baltimore, Inc. v. Varilease Technology Finance Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Maryland courts will pierce the corporate veil only where necessary to prevent fraud or to enforce a paramount equity; among the factors to be considered in determining whether the corporate veil must be pierced to enforce a paramount equity are gross undercapitalization of the corporation, a dominant shareholder's siphoning of corporate funds, the absence of corporate records, or other indicators that the corporation is merely a facade for the shareholder's operations.

Title: International Financial Services Corp. v. Chromas Technologies Canada, Inc.

Title: Matheson v. Virgin Islands Community Bank, Corp.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Remedy of "piercing the corporate veil" is equitable remedy whereby court disregards existence of corporation to make corporation's individual principals and their personal assets liable for debts of corporation; application of this remedy is appropriate when court must prevent fraud, injustice, or when recognition of corporate entity would defeat public policy or shield someone from liability.

Title: Hildreth v. Tidewater Equipment Co., Inc
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Although courts will, in a proper case, disregard the corporate entity and deal with substance rather than form, as though a corporation did not exist, shareholders generally are not held individually liable for debts or obligations of a corporation except where it is necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.

Title: Hildreth v. Tidewater Equipment Co., Inc
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Courts will apply the "alter ego" doctrine when the plaintiff shows: (1) complete domination, not only of the finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of the statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that such control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of unregistered foreign corporation was not personally liable for corporate debt.

Title: Hildreth v. Tidewater Equipment Co., Inc

Headnote: Because piercing the corporate veil is founded on equity, where no fraud is shown, the plaintiff must show that an inequitable result, involving fundamental unfairness, will result from a failure to disregard the corporate form.

Title: Kaplan v. Aspen Knolls Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To assert claim for individual liability under alter ego theory, plaintiff must demonstrate that (1) person exercised such complete dominion and control in respect to transaction attacked that corporation had at one time no separate will of its own and (2) that this domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff, which proximately caused plaintiff's injury; additionally, even under liberal pleading standards, plaintiff must plead facts sufficient to show that these elements are satisfied. Headnote: In determining whether corporate form may be disregarded, courts consider (1) whether entities in question have ignored independence of their separate operations, (2) whether defendant employed multiplicity of entities as part of artifice or scheme to defraud, and (3) whether holding corporate form inviolate would lead to substantial injustice or inequity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Plaintiff was not judicially estopped from asserting that it was not bound by arbitration clause.

Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced to hold an alter ego liable for the commitments of its instrumentality only if: (1) the owner exercised complete control over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such control was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory Turkmenistan government could not be compelled to arbitrate a contract claim.

Title: In re iPCS, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, alter ego theory requires that corporate structure cause fraud or similar injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Creditors' committee would be allowed to pursue alter ego claims on behalf of estate.

Title: Dominguez v. Payne
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Because disregarding the corporate fiction is an equitable doctrine, Texas takes a flexible fact-specific approach focusing on equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issues existed regarding whether shareholder was alter ego of corporate developer.

Title: In re Petition of Garcia Avila
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil or establish alter ego liability under New York law, creditor must show domination and control by the shareholder or parent, the use of that position to commit a wrong or perpetrate a fraud, and injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Foreign debtors were entitled to injunctive relief preventing interference with bond proceeds.

Title: Goldstein v. Mortenson
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Appellate court disregards the corporate fiction, even though corporate formalities have been observed and corporate and individual property have been kept separately, when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Norwood Group, Inc. v. Phillips
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: The court will pierce the corporate veil and assess individual liability on the shareholders where the shareholders have used the corporate identity to promote an injustice or fraud on the plaintiffs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Action to pierce corporate veil was governed by limitations period for action to enforce judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Miner v. Fashion Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: A corporate veil will be pierced where: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual are nonexistent, and (2) the circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor may file a new action to pierce the corporate veil of a judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: National Hotel Associates ex rel. M.E. Venture Management, Inc. v. O. Ahlborg & Sons, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: The criteria for piercing the corporate veil to impose liability on non-corporate defendants vary with the particular circumstances of each case; however, when the facts of a particular case render it unjust and inequitable to consider the subject corporation a separate entity, courts will not hesitate to disregard the corporate form and treat the defendant as an individual who is personally liable for the debts of the disregarded corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. First corporation was operated as an instrumentality of second corporation.

Title: District Council No. 9 v. APC Painting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, generally piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Arbitration. Wage deficiency arbitration award was enforceable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Iceland Telecom, Ltd. v. Information Systems and Networks Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, although courts will, in a proper case, disregard the corporate entity and deal with substance rather than form, as though a corporation did not exist, shareholders are generally not held individually liable for the debts and obligations of a corporation except where it is necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity; much like individual stockholders, a corporate parent also will not be liable for the debts/obligations of its subsidiary absent the showing of the same two factors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced in order to hold the founder and parent company liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Vebeliunas
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff must prove the following: (1) owner exercised such control over corporation that corporation has become a mere instrumentality of owner; (2) that the owner used this control to commit fraud or "other wrong"; and (3) that this fraud or wrong resulted in an unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Trustee failed to establish control required to pierce veil of trust.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Transcolor Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, courts will pierce the corporate veil only when necessary to prevent fraud or a paramount inequity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Insider of debtor-corporation was liable for fraud.

Title: Multi-Media Holdings, Inc. v. Piedmont Center, 15 LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, courts may pierce the corporate veil to remedy injustices which arise where a party has overextended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetrate fraud or evade contractual or tort responsibility; the theory applies when there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the owners no longer exist.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Evidence was sufficient to establish parent corporation's ratification of lease assignment by lessee, which merged with subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Evergreen Security, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Florida law, plaintiff must demonstrate by preponderance of evidence: (1) that shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent, and that shareholder was in fact alter ego of corporation; (2) that corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose; and (3) that fraudulent or improper use of corporate form caused injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Commissions paid for soliciting investors in Ponzi scheme were made with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight L.P.
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: The piercing of a veil is justified when the unity of interest and ownership is such that the separate personalities of the corporation and/or limited partnership and the individual no longer exist, and adherence to that separateness would create an injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Virginia recognizes concept of outsider reverse piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mountview Plaza Associates, Inc. v. World Wide Pet Supply, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of separate legal entity when a corporation is a mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock, and under such circumstances the general rule, which recognizes the individuality of corporate entities and the independent character of each in respect to their corporate transactions, and the obligations incurred by each in the course of such transactions, will be disregarded, where the interests of justice and righteous dealing so demand.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Default judgment conclusively determined shareholder's liability for corporation's breach of lease agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mountview Plaza Associates, Inc. v. World Wide Pet Supply, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Instrumentality test for determining whether to pierce corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Default judgment conclusively determined shareholder's liability for corporation's breach of lease agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. Public Interest Research Group v. Atlantic Salmon of Maine, LLC.

Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, three things must be proved: lack of corporate independence, fraudulent intent, and manifest injustice.

Title: Lane v. Montana Fourth Judicial Dist. Court

Title: Meadowbrook-Richman, Inc. v. Associated Financial Corp.

Title: Firstar Bank, N.A. v. Faul Chevrolet, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois courts will only find that piercing of corporate veil is proper where failure to do so would: (1) unfairly enrich one of parties; (2) allow parent corporation to escape responsibility where it had created subsidiary's liabilities and was cause of subsidiary's inability to meet those liabilities; (3) allow former partners to ignore obligations; or (4) uphold corporate arrangement to keep assets in liability-free corporation while placing liabilities on asset-free corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Automobile dealership's creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Lambert v. Kazinetz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: The corporate veil can be pierced, under Ohio law, to hold an individual corporate officer or shareholder liable for the wrongs committed by the corporation, when: (1) the individual to be held liable exerted such complete control that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Officer's personal liability might not depend on piercing of corporate veil.

Title: S.E.C. v. Hickey
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: California law recognizes alter ego relationship, such that corporation's liabilities may be imposed on an individual, only when two conditions are met: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that individuality, or separateness, of person and corporation has ceased, and (2) adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, that fraud or similar injustice relative to the use of a corporate form can be shown is immaterial, and thus will not constitute that which is required to pierce a corporate veil, if such fraud or injustice has already been remedied.

Title: KLM Industries, Inc. v. Tylutki
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Instrumentality rule concerning piercing the corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of. Title: Department of Transp. v. Airlie Park, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Courts will only pierce the corporate veil where applying the corporate fiction would defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime; in such cases, those who are responsible for the existence of the corporation are prevented by the courts from using its separate existence to accomplish an unconscionable result.

Headnote: The concept of piercing the corporate veil is equitable in nature and courts should pierce the corporate veil only under exceptional circumstances.

Title: In re Icarus Holdings, LLC.

Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied under Georgia law to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.

Title: In re Icarus Holdings, LLC.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Macon Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, harm to third party is not prerequisite for piercing corporate veil; rather, court looks to whether there has been any abuse of corporate form which has resulted in inequities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Alter ego claims were included in property of debtor-corporation's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bank of America v. Musselman
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, in order to pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show that the corporate entity is the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of the officers or directors which plaintiffs seeks to sue or charge personally, and that the corporation was a device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime. Va.Code 1950, § 13.1-690 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Lender was barred from recovering corporation's defaulted loan from officer.

Title: Peetoom v. Swanson
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil fastens liability on an individual or entity that uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct that person's or entity's business; such liability arises from fraud or injustice perpetrated, not on the corporation but on third persons dealing with the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Action to pierce the corporate veil was governed by five-year statute of limitations.

Headnote: Under Virginia law, in order to prevail upon alter ego claim, party must show that individual uses alter ego to evade a personal obligation, to perpetrate fraud or crime, to commit injustice, or to gain unfair advantage.

Title: Old Republic Nat. Title Ins. Co. v. Moskowitz
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: To successfully pierce the corporate veil, a third party must show that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: Community Care Centers, Inc. v. Hamilton
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Courts are reluctant to disregard corporate identity and do so only to protect third parties from fraud or injustice when transacting business with a corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Community Care Centers, Inc. v. Hamilton
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In deciding whether a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has met its burden, courts consider whether the party has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization,(2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence that corporation transferred its operations informally did not require piercing of corporate veil.

Title: Al Sayegh Bros. Trading (LLC) v. Doral Trading & Export, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil and hold corporate officer liable under New York law for debts of corporation, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court would not pierce corporate veil to hold affiliated company liable for corporation's debts.

Title: APS Sports Collectibles, Inc. v. Sports Time, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, plaintiff attempting to make individual liable for acts of corporation must show (1) that there exists such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of individual and corporation no longer exist, and (2) that there exist circumstances such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would likely produce unjust or inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Officers and shareholders were not liable for corporation's alleged unlawful transfer of assets.

Title: Howell v. Hilton Hotels Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: "Alter ego," as a basis for piercing corporate veil, applies when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Funds paid to alleged partner as profits were not partnership property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Kentuckiana Truck & Trailer Repair, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: In the Sixth Circuit, three facts must exist in order for a court to ignore the corporate fiction: plaintiff must show that the domination over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, that the domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act, and that the injury or unjust event resulted in damage to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. The evidence did not support equitable subordination of bank's claim.

Title: In re Woolum
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded where separate personalities of corporation and individual stockholder no longer exist and where, if acts are treated as those of corporation alone, some inequitable result will follow.

Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To decide whether a plaintiff has met the burden necessary to pierce the corporate veil, courts consider whether the plaintiff has presented evidence showing: (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities, (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.

Title: Albee v. Krasnoff
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: The concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied in Georgia to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetrate fraud, or evade contractual or tort responsibility.

Title: Litchfield Asset Management Corp. v. Howell
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) complete control of finances, policy, and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act, and (3) that the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Virtualmagic Asia, Inc. v. Fil-Cartoons, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The two principal questions to establish alter ego are whether there is such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and whether there would be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.

Title: Virtualmagic Asia, Inc. v. Fil-Cartoons, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Even if the unity of interest and ownership element is shown, the alter ego doctrine will not be applied absent evidence that an injustice would result from the recognition of separate corporate identities; difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy this standard.

Title: Wady v. Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Essence of alter ego doctrine is that justice be done, and thus corporate form will be disregarded only in narrowly defined circumstances and only when ends of justice so require.

Title: Wady v. Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Before alter ego doctrine may be invoked, the following must be established: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and (2) that, if acts are treated as those of corporation alone, inequitable result will follow; only difference in wording is used in stating same concept where entity sought to be held liable is another corporation instead of individual.

Title: Harwood v. International Estate Planners

Headnote: Under California law, although there is no litmus test to determine when the corporate veil will be pierced, two general requirements are (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the person no longer exist and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.

Title: Becker v. Graber Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Liability may be imposed on an individual controlling a corporation as an "instrumentality" when he had: (1) complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Orange County Sunbird Aviation v. County of Orange
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Courts do not weigh as a separate factor the inequitable result part of the alter ego test, nor do they decline to pierce the corporate veil in an otherwise proper case based on an independent evaluation of the equities; if the facts indicate improper use of the corporate form, that finding dictates the conclusion that it would be inequitable to honor form over substance.

Title: U.S. ex rel. Siewick v. Jamieson Science and Engineering, Inc.
