Headnote: Factors in determining whether federal common law supports piercing corporate veil are: (1) whether there is such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and (2) whether inequitable result will follow if acts are treated as those of corporation alone.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Former employee's supervisor was not an employer under False Claims Act's retaliation provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Shelton v. Clements
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a party must show fraud in asserting the corporate existence or must show that recognition of the corporate existence will result in injustice or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Evidence was sufficient to support finding that builder breached contract to construct log cabin.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Quantum Color Graphics, LLC v. Fan Association Event Photo GmbH
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, to pierce the corporate veil and hold alter egos jointly liable, a plaintiff must be able to prove (1) a unity of interest and ownership that causes the separate personalities of the corporations and the individual to no longer exist; and (2) the presence of circumstances under which adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Allegations were sufficient to support exercise of specific jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Yankee Microwave, Inc. v. Petricca Communications Systems, Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Berkshire.
Headnote: The doctrine of corporate disregard is an equitable tool that authorizes courts, in rare situations, to ignore corporate formalities, where such disregard is necessary to provide a meaningful remedy for injuries and to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Insolvent corporation's repayment of advances made by related corporation was not a fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Agway, Inc. v. Brooks
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: The Supreme Court will look beyond the corporation to its shareholders for liability, that is, pierce the corporate veil, where the corporate form has been used to perpetrate a fraud, and also where the needs of justice dictate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder of closely-held corporation was personally liable for debts of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Agway, Inc. v. Brooks
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: In cases not involving fraudulent activity, the court will look to the facts and circumstances of each case to determine whether the corporate veil should be pierced in the interests of fairness, equity, and the public need.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder of closely-held corporation was personally liable for debts of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Tucker Land Co. v. State of California
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Constituents of joint powers agency were not individually liable on contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Worth v. Tyer
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: To overcome presumption of shareholder protection from individual liability, a party must show, in addition to the interrelation of a corporation and its shareholders, that the protection must be disregarded to prevent fraud or the promotion of injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Damages. Punitive damages awarded to Title VII plaintiff were not excessive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Cherry Creek Card & Party Shop, Inc. v. Hallmark Marketing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil is equitable in nature and as such is reserved for situations where some impropriety or injustice is evident.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory was not equitably estopped from asserting it was not bound by arbitration clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Cherry Creek Card & Party Shop, Inc. v. Hallmark Marketing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced if: (1) there is such unity of interest and lack of respect given to separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders that personalities and assets of corporation and individuals are indistinct, and (2) adherence to corporate fiction would sanction fraud, promote injustice, or lead to evasion of legal obligations.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory was not equitably estopped from asserting it was not bound by arbitration clause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Beswick v. City Of Philadelphia
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The corporate entity may not be used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud or defend crime, and the form will be disregarded whenever justice or public policy demand.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Public Safety. City was not liable for heart attack victim's death arising from 911 call-taker's improper private ambulance referral.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kellers Systems, Inc. v. Transport Intern. Pool, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To establish a veil-piercing claim under Illinois law, claimant must prove two elements: there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual or other corporation no longer exist, and circumstances must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Contract's indemnification provisions did not encompass fee-shifting in lawsuit between parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Shanghai Automation Instrument Co., Ltd. v. Kuei
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, corporation's veil may be pierced, and corporation may be deemed alter ego of individual, where: (1) unity of interest and ownership exists between personality of corporation and individual owner; and (2) failure to disregard their separate identities would result in inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Default judgment was entered against fewer than all defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Good v. Holstein
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Court will not hesitate to treat as identical a corporation and the individuals owning all its stock and assets whenever justice and public policy demand and when the rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced thereby nor the theory of corporate entity made useless.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation was owner's alter ego for purposes of first and second mortgages owned by owner and corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Good v. Holstein
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate form will be disregarded only when the entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation was owner's alter ego for purposes of first and second mortgages owned by owner and corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Monteau v. Reis Trucking & Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: It is not the presence or absence of any particular factor that is determinative in piercing the corporate veil; rather, it is a combination of factors which, when taken together with an element of injustice or abuse of corporate privilege, suggest that the corporate entity attacked had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, and was therefore a mere instrumentality or tool of its shareholders.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS - Bonds. Company that procured construction contract could not maintain action on bonds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Vinales
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Virginia, Roanoke Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, proof that some person may dominate or control corporation, or may treat it as mere department, instrumentality, agency or the like, is not sufficient basis, without more, for piercing corporate veil; party seeking to pierce corporate veil must also establish that corporation was device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Petitioning creditors claims were subject to bona fide dispute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: MAG Portfolio Consult, GMBH v. Merlin Biomed Group LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, court may pierce corporate veil where: (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Successor companies could not be compelled to arbitrate under agreement they were not party to.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Official Committee of Unsecured Creditors v. R.F. Lafferty & Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: In Pennsylvania, courts will disregard the corporate entity only in limited circumstances when the form is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. In pari delicto defense precluded recovery by innocent victims of Ponzi scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Commissioner, Dept. of Environmental Management v. RLG, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: The corporate veil is pierced only where it is clear that the corporation is merely a shell for conducting the defendant's own business and where the misuse of the corporate form constitutes a fraud or promotes injustice.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Solid Waste. Landfill's corporate officer was personally liable for environmental violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >

Headnote: Under Maryland law, corporate veil is pierced only in unusual cases where necessary to prevent fraud or enforce paramount inequity.

Title: Burlington Northern & Santa Fe Ry. Co. v. Phillips Petroleum Company
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Oklahoma law permits court to disregard corporate entity, only if corporation is used: (1) to defeat public convenience, (2) justify wrong, (3) to perpetrate fraud whether actual or implied, (4) to defend crime.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lessee was liable to owner for cost of remediation of contamination at bulk oil facility.

Title: Great Neck Plaza, L.P. v. Le Peep Restaurants, LLC
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. I.
Headnote: The corporate entity may be disregarded, and the corporate veil may be pierced, if not doing so would defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or protect fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Alter ego and fraudulent transfer could be litigated in garnishment proceeding.

Title: Government of Virgin Islands, Bureau of Internal Revenue v. Lansdale
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix.
Headnote: Although the term "alter ego" is often used synonymously with "piercing the corporate veil," it is but one basis, under Delaware law, for bypassing the corporate shield, and other relevant factors in determining whether to disregard the corporate entity include whether it is in the interest of justice, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract, public wrong, or equitable considerations among members of the corporation, are involved.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Corporations' acts and omissions could be attributed to owners to satisfy Virgin Islands' long-arm statute.

Title: Government of Virgin Islands, Bureau of Internal Revenue v. Lansdale
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix.
Headnote: Essentially, what plaintiff must show in seeking piercing of corporate veil, under California law, is that the shareholders' interests and those of the corporation have been so unified that their separate personalities no longer exist, and if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Corporations' acts and omissions could be attributed to owners to satisfy Virgin Islands' long-arm statute.

Title: Lifshutz v. Lifshutz
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine has two elements: (1) such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased, and (2) a finding that holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.

Headnote: In equity, a corporate entity may be disregarded and held to be the mere alter ego of a shareholder or shareholders in various circumstances where necessary to prevent fraud or other injustice.

Title: Graham Graphics, Inc. v. Baer Marketing Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: The fiction of separate corporate identity of two corporations will not be extended to permit one of the corporations to evade its just obligations or to promote fraud or illegality or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Successor parent corporation was liable for subsidiary's debt to printer.

Title: Paul v. Destito
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Georgia courts pierce the corporate veil to remedy injustices which arise where a party has overextended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetrate fraud, or evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Status as shareholder and former director did not bar claim of alter eqo liability against other shareholders.

Title: Heflin v. Koszela
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: To impose liability on a corporation for the acts of its employees, the facts of a particular case must render it unjust and inequitable to consider the subject corporation a separate entity such as when the corporate entity is used to defeat a public convenience, justify a wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.

Title: Heflin v. Koszela
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: To invoke the equitable alter ego doctrine, there must be a concurrence of two circumstances: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) the observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or an inequitable result would follow.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE - Claims. Action against estate, after probate claim was disallowed, was time-barred.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Heflin v. Koszela
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Whether, under the alter ego test, observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or an inequitable result would follow is addressed to the conscience of the court, and the circumstances under which it will be met will vary with each case; however, it must be shown that the corporation itself played a role in the inequitable conduct at issue.
Document Preview: ESTATE PLANNING AND PROBATE - Claims. Action against estate, after probate claim was disallowed, was time-barred.

Title: Middle Tennessee News Co., Inc. v. Charnel of Cincinnati, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Indiana courts are reluctant to disregard corporate form, but will do so to prevent fraud or injustice to third parties.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Debtor Protections. Judgment did not violate bankruptcy automatic stay.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Middle Tennessee News Co., Inc. v. Charnel of Cincinnati, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate under Indiana law, plaintiffs must show that corporate form was so ignored, controlled or manipulated that it was merely instrumentality of another, and that misuse of corporate form would constitute fraud or promote injustice, pursuant to eight-factor test requiring court to balance evidence of (1) undercapitalization, (2) absence of corporate records, (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors, (4) use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities, (5) payment by corporation of individual obligations, (6) commingling of assets and affairs, (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities, and (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling or manipulating corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Debtor Protections. Judgment did not violate bankruptcy automatic stay.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Nordstrom
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, alter ego liability will be found when: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and the controlling individual that their separate personalities no longer exist, and (2) the facts are such that inequity will result otherwise.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Proof of subjective intent to injure was not needed under willful and malicious injury dischargeability exception.

Title: Fiumetto v. Garrett Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must demonstrate the following: (1) such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) circumstances such that an adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unemployment Compensation. Private right of action for retaliatory discharge for claiming unemployment compensation could be implied.

Title: McFarland v. Brier
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: To impose liability on a corporation for the acts of its employees, the facts of a particular case must render it unjust and inequitable to consider the subject corporation a separate entity, such as when the corporate entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.

Title: H.S.W. Enterprises, Inc. v. Woo Lae Oak, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Virginia courts pierce the corporate veil of immunity only in extraordinary cases, and require plaintiff to show both that (1) the corporate entity was the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of the individuals sought to be charged personally, and (2) that the corporation was a device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Purported holder of trademarks did not breach covenant of good faith and fair dealing by not disclosing marks.

Title: King v. Modern Music Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: It is the general rule that a corporation is an entity separate and apart from the persons composing it; however, both law and equity disregard the distinct existence and treat them as identical when necessary to circumvent fraud, protect the rights of third persons, and accomplish justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate shield would not be disregarded so as to hold company, which leased premises to tavern, responsible for motorists' injuries.

Title: King v. Modern Music Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Courts may disregard the corporate entity, and treat the corporation as an association of persons, if used: (1) to defeat public convenience; (2) to justify wrong; (3) to perpetrate fraud, whether actual or implied; or (4) to defend crime.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate shield would not be disregarded so as to hold company, which leased premises to tavern, responsible for motorists' injuries.

Title: King v. Modern Music Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Corporate shield may be disregarded when it is essential in the interest of justice to do so, or where the corporate shield is used to defeat an overriding public policy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate shield would not be disregarded so as to hold company, which leased premises to tavern, responsible for motorists' injuries.

Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight Ltd. Partnership

Title: Mallard Automotive Group, Ltd. v. LeClair Management Corp.

Title: Soerries v. Dancause
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: The concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied to remedy injustices which arise where a party has overextended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetrate fraud, or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.

Title: Carter Enterprises, Inc. v. Ashland Specialty Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil to hold corporation's owner responsible for corporation's liabilities involves examination of relationship between corporation and its owner and of degree to which corporation observes, vel non, formalities required of it by state; if court finds that a blurring of line between corporation and its owner exists and that equity demands it, court will conclude that what appears to be two separate entities existing in parallel is, for certain purposes, a single entity.

Title: Carter Jones Lumber Co. v. LTV Steel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, to hold shareholder liable for wrongdoing of corporation requires proof of: control over corporation so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; control over corporation exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity; and injury or unjust loss resulting to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder was jointly liable cleanup costs.

Title: In re Tobin
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Where corporate and individual affairs are badly intermingled and it would be unjust to recognize the distinction between individuals and corporations, courts will hold individuals liable for corporate debts and vice versa.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Imputed fraud would not support finding of nondischargeability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Tobin
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Determination as to whether to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholder personally liable for corporate debts is based upon three factors: amount of respect given to separate identity of corporation by its shareholders, the degree of injustice visited on litigants by recognition of corporate entity, and fraudulent intent of incorporators.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Imputed fraud would not support finding of nondischargeability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Aetna Elec. Distributing Co. v. Homestead Elec., Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, the plaintiff must show that the owner exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: D.S.I. v. Natare Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, the Court of Appeals will examine several factors, including the following: (1) undercapitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representations by corporate shareholders or directors; (4) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities; (5) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Swimming pool business's corporate veil was pierced to hold owner liable for frivolous suit sanctions.

Title: Smith v. McLeod Distributing, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Although courts are reluctant to disregard a corporate entity, they may do so to prevent fraud or unfairness to third parties.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold another corporation liable for commercial debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Victory Lake Marine, Inc. v. Velduis
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: Court will disregard a corporation's identity where the corporation has been used to commit fraud, violate a legal duty, or perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the rights of another.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Fact issues regarding corporate tenant precluded summary judgment against officers personally.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Wright v. Cleo Wallace Centers
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil and hold another entity liable for a corporation's conduct on an alter ego theory, court must determine: (1) whether there was such a unity of interest and lack of respect given to the separate entity of the corporation by its shareholders that the personalities and assets of the corporation and the individual are indistinct, and (2) whether adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Complaint stated claim under False Claim Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Longo Constr., Inc. v. ASAP Tech. Serv., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Corporate form may be disregarded, and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by a corporation, when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported jury's decision to pierce corporate veil and hold principal personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Goya Foods, Inc. v. Unanue
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil may be disregarded where challenger shows: (1) complete domination of corporation by its alleged alter ego; and (2) use of that domination to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff.

Headnote: Under Michigan law, corporate veil may be pierced if: (1) corporate entity is mere instrumentality of another entity or individual, (2) corporate entity was used to commit fraud or wrong, and (3) there was unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.

Title: Dews v. Ratterree
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied in Georgia to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud, or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.

Title: City of Dearborn v. DLZ Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, corporate veil may be pierced only where otherwise separate corporate existence has been used to subvert justice or cause result that is contrary to some other clearly overriding public policy.

Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: While Virginia law permits actions to disregard separate legal existence of corporations, piercing of the corporate veil should be permitted only when necessary to promote justice and only under exceptional circumstances, such as where corporate insider has so abused or disregarded the corporate form that the corporation becomes the alter ego of the insider; in these instances, if certain requirements are met, corporate veil may be pierced so that creditor can reach assets of shareholder to satisfy obligations of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Predicted Virginia law would recognize reverse piercing action.

Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, piercing corporate veil is justified when the unity of interest and ownership is such that the separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and to adhere to that separateness would work an injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Predicted Virginia law would recognize reverse piercing action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law on piercing corporate veil, it is not enough that plaintiff establish that the individual had control over the corporation or that corporate entity was simply the alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of individuals sought to be charged personally; rather, plaintiff must establish that shareholder has used corporation to evade personal obligation, to perpetrate fraud or a crime, to commit an injustice, or to gain an unfair advantage.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Predicted Virginia law would recognize reverse piercing action.

Title: C.F. Trust, Inc. v. First Flight Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, the "legal wrong" requirement for corporate veil piercing is correctly understood as a broad category that includes using the corporate form to (i) evade personal obligations, (ii) perpetuate fraud or a crime, or (iii) commit injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Predicted Virginia law would recognize reverse piercing action.

Title: Sonora Diamond Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Under the "alter ego doctrine," when the corporate form is used to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, the courts will ignore the corporate entity, and deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons or organizations actually controlling the corporation, in most instances the equitable owners.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Canadian parent corporation of Nevada subsidiary was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sonora Diamond Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked: there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Canadian parent corporation of Nevada subsidiary was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Title: Sonora Diamond Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Absent evidence of any wrongdoing by either corporation or persons exercising control, or any evidence of injustice flowing from the recognition of separate corporate identity, alter ego doctrine cannot be invoked.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Canadian parent corporation of Nevada subsidiary was not subject to personal jurisdiction.

Title: Snell v. Bob Fisher Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maine.
Headnote: Under Maine law, before court may pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must establish that (1) defendant abused privilege of a separate corporate identity, and (2) an unjust or inequitable result would occur if the court recognized the separate corporate existence; this two-part analysis requires a balancing of the policy of encouraging business development with the policy of protecting those who deal with the corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Corporate veil would not be pierced to establish jurisdiction.

Title: Thomas v. Lytle
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, court will pierce corporate veil upon showing of: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked, such that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) use of such control by corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) injury or unjust loss proximately caused by such control and breach of duty.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Entertainment. Royalty payments had to be calculated based on income to sublicensee.

Title: In re Brown

Headnote: Under Idaho law, there are two requirements for piercing the corporate veil: (1) that there be such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; and (2) that if acts are treated as those of the corporation, an inequitable result will follow.

Title: Williams v. Vanaria
Court: Massachusetts Appellate Division, District Court Department, Northern District.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil in rare particular situations in order to prevent gross inequity, where a corporation has been formed or managed contrary to public policy or for fraudulent reasons.-Williams v. Vanaria.
Document Preview: This is an action against a corporate employer and individual officers of the corporation to recover payment allegedly due under the plaintiff's employment agreement for expenses he incurred. The record indicates that individual defendants Steven and Robert Vanaria were officers and directors of defendant Vanaria Contracting Co., Inc. (Vanaria), a Massachusetts corporation primarily engaged in the construction business of commercial site excavation. At some point in the mid 1980's, plaintiff Robert Williams became employed by Vanaria as a truck driver. He received an hourly wage, plus gasoline and other expenses for a truck that he drove for the company and between his home and Vanaria job sites. The plaintiff's wages and expense reimbursements were at all times paid by Vanaria corporate checks drawn on Vanaria corporate accounts. The plaintiff was listed as an employee on Vanaria's books, and the required taxes, insurance and other payroll deductions were taken by...

Title: Osloond v. Osloond
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and obtain access to corporate funds so as to satisfy judgment against a corporation's officers, directors, or shareholders, the following two requirements must be met: (1) was there such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and its shareholders, officers or directors are indistinct or non-existent; and (2) would adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence sanction fraud, promote injustice or inequitable consequences or lead to an evasion of legal obligations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Former wife was not entitled to levy against assets of former husband's corporation without piercing corporate veil.

Title: LaSalle Nat. Bank v. Perelman
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In order to prevail on claim to pierce corporate veil and hold the corporation's shareholders liable under Delaware law, plaintiff must prove that corporate form causes fraud or similar injustice.
Document Preview: Successor indenture trustee for notes issued by subsidiary corporations brought action against officers and directors of subsidiaries and their parent corporations for breach of fiduciary duties to noteholders when they used proceeds from notes to pay dividends to parent corporations. On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, McKelvie, J., held that: (1) officers and directors did not breach fiduciary duties to indenture holders; (2) officers and directors of parent corporations did not intentionally interfere with indentures; and (3) officers and directors of subsidiaries did not commit fraud or similar injustice so as to permit piercing corporate veil. Motion granted.

Title: Brevet Intern., Inc. v. Great Plains Luggage Co.
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether equity demands piercing the corporate veil include (1) undercapitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) absence of corporate records, (4) payment by the corporation of individual obligations, (5) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporate directors, and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegality; first four factors may be grouped in "separate corporate identity" prong, while final two may be grouped in "fraud or inequitable consequences" prong.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, courts will not pierce the corporate veil except in cases of fraud, injustice, or the like.
Document Preview: Transportation broker brought suit in state court against freight forwarders, alleging breach of contract. After action was removed, and order was entered with respect to discovery disputes, 181 F.R.D. 229, defendants moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Arcara, J., adopted the report and recommendation of Foschio, United States Magistrate Judge, which held that: (1) fact that transportation broker had failed to obtain license from Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC) to perform brokering services did not render agreement unenforceable; (2) fact issues as to whether contractual agreement existed, and if so, nature of relationship created, precluded summary judgment; and (3) broker failed to establish basis to pierce corporate veil of forwarder which was not party to agreement. Report and recommendation adopted, and motion granted in part and denied in part.

Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.

Headnote: Under New Jersey law, purpose of doctrine which allows corporate veil to be pierced in cases of fraud, injustice, or the like is to prevent the use of an independent corporation to defeat the ends of justice, perpetrate fraud, accomplish a crime, or otherwise evade the law.

Title: Pointer (U.S.A.), Inc. v. H & D Foods Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law corporations are to be regarded as separate entities, except in rare instances when it is necessary to look beyond the corporate form for the purpose of defeating fraud or wrong, or for the remedying of injuries.
Document Preview: Provider of credit to corporation engaged in importation of seafood sued sole shareholder, seeking to pierce corporate veil after corporation became insolvent and went out of business. Parties cross moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Griesa, J., held that: (1) provider's knowledge that corporation was short of capital precluded veil piercing, and (2) shareholder did not misuse corporate form by temporarily taking money from corporation to finance real estate venture of another corporation. Summary judgment for shareholder.

Parties cross moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Griesa, J., held that: (1) provider's knowledge that corporation was short of capital precluded veil piercing, and (2) shareholder did not misuse corporate form by temporarily taking money from corporation to finance real estate venture of another corporation. Title: U.S. v. Scherping
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, disregard of the corporate entity requires not only that a number of factors be present, such as failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, siphoning of funds by the individual, absence of records for the entity, and the existence of the entity as merely a facade for the individual, but also that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: Government brought collection action against individuals and two business trusts, seeking foreclosure of its tax liens upon defendants' real property. The United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, Paul A. Magnuson, Chief Judge, granted summary judgment for government, and defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, McMillian, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) action was not barred by statute of limitations; (2) reverse piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold trusts liable for individuals' tax liabilities; and (3) individuals' transfers of property to trusts were fraudulent conveyances. Affirmed.

Title: Robert's Hawaii School Bus, Inc. v. Laupahoehoe Transp. Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Hawai‘i.
Headnote: Before a corporation's acts and obligations can be legally recognized as those of a particular person, and vice versa, it must be made to appear that: [1] the corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but that there is such a unity of interest that the individuality, or separateness, of such person and corporation has ceased, and [2] that the facts are such that an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would, under the particular circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Garden State Tanning, Inc. v. Mitchell Mfg. Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Michigan law a corporation is treated as a separate entity unless there is a showing that (1) the corporate entity was a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual, (2) the corporate entity was used to commit a fraud or wrong, and (3) there was an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: Creditor of corporate subsidiary sued parent, seeking to recover under guaranty and for alleged fraudulent transfer of assets of subsidiary to third party. Parent moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Katz, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) there were fact questions regarding scope of guaranty precluding recovery on breach of contract, unjust enrichment and quantum meruit theories; (2) transfer of assets was not fraudulent under Michigan statutes; (3) transfer was not fraudulent under Pennsylvania common law; (4) transfer was not fraudulent under Michigan common law; and (5) creditor failed to establish that subsidiary was alter ego of parent, under laws of Michigan or Pennsylvania. Motion granted in part, denied in part.

Title: Doe v. Gelineau
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Although the criteria for piercing the corporate veil of limited liability vary with the particular circumstances of each case, one overriding factor is omnipresent: the corporate entity should be disregarded and treated as an association of persons only when the facts of a particular case render it unjust and inequitable to consider the subject corporation a separate entity.

Title: Brick Const. Corp. v. CEI Development Corp.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Toshiba America Medical Systems, Inc. v. Mobile Medical Systems, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder was liable for corporation's breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >

Title: GAVCO, Inc. v. Chem-Trend Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, whether corporation is a mere instrumentality depends on: (1) domination and control of corporate entity; (2) use of that domination and control to perpetrate a fraud or wrong; and (3) proximate causation of wrong complained of by domination and control.
Document Preview: Independent sales representative sued manufacturer for unpaid sales commissions following termination of parties' contract. Manufacturer counterclaimed for, inter alia, breach of contract, unfair trade practices, and conspiracy. Representative moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Horn, United States Chief Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) depositions taken in related lawsuit to which representative was not a party were inadmissible; (2) contract required payment of earned commissions regardless of representative's outside activities; (3) issue of fact existed as to whether outside activities constituted termination by malfeasance under North Carolina sales commission statute; (4) issue of fact existed as to whether corporation was representative's alter ego; and (5) issue of fact existed as to whether outside activities constituted breach. Motion granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Stratton Oakmont, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is an equitable doctrine, for it is a means to achieve the end of preventing fraud and abuse of corporate separateness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. SIPA trustee's reverse veil-piercing theory survived dismissal motions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Miranda v. Smyrna Building Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Term, New York., Second Department.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, there must be a showing that the corporation was dominated as to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was the instrument of fraud or otherwise resulted in wrongful or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Civil Court of the City of New York has jurisdiction to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Castillo v. M.E.K. Const., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: Distinct corporate identity will be maintained unless to do so would subvert the ends of justice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. General contractor and subcontractor were entitled to immunity under exclusive remedy provision of workers' compensation statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Residential Warranty Corp. v. Bancroft Homes Greenspring Valley, Inc.
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil only based on fraud or proof that it is necessary to enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mere speculation regarding fraud was insufficient to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Stanford University Hosp. v. Federal Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under California law, when necessary to redress fraud, protect rights of third persons, or prevent palpable injustice, law and equity will intervene and cast aside legal fiction of independent corporate existence, as distinguished from those who hold and own corporate capital stock, and deal with corporation and stockholders as identical entities with identical duties and obligations.
Document Preview: Insured nonprofit corporations brought suits seeking coverage, under crime insurance policies, for misappropriations by their payroll tax service. The United States District Court for the Northern District of California, Claudia Wilken, J., 1995 WL 912346, granted summary judgment for insureds, and insurer appealed. The Court of Appeals, Keep, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) payroll tax service was authorized representative of insureds within meaning of exclusionary clause, and (2) thefts of insureds' funds by officers and employees of payroll tax service were acts of authorized representatives under the exclusion. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Brown v. Vitelcom, Inc.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Thomas and St. John.
Headnote: Under "alter ego test," court may pierce corporate veil and disregard corporate autonomy to prevent illegality or injustice.
Document Preview: Employee, a black woman from Dominica, brought action against employer, its parent corporation, and other subsidiary corporations, alleging discrimination and retaliation based on race or national origin, under Title VII and §1981. On cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Moore, Chief Judge, held that: (1) fact issues existed on Title VII and §1981 claims, and (2) parent corporation was properly named defendant. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Union Pacific R. Co. v. Midland Equities Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil, under Missouri law, there must be showing of control to point of dominance, used to commit fraud or wrong, proximately causing injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Railroad sued real estate development limited partnership, seeking to recover under contract calling for it to modify trackage to accommodate proposed development. After judgment was entered in its favor, 45 F. Supp.2d 685, railroad moved to pierce corporate veil of general partner to reach assets of affiliated corporation having general real estate development responsibilities on project. The District Court, Noce, United States Magistrate Judge, held that absence of fraud or any concealment precluded piercing of veil. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, courts may, under unusual circumstances, disregard corporate form, particularly to defeat fraud or remedy an injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced in order to permit creditor's proof of claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Rose Ocko Foundation, Inc. v. Lebovits
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Decision to pierce the corporate veil requires a showing that the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Non-profit Entities. Sale of nonprofit corporation's chief asset was subject to judicial scrutiny.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re KDI Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, three elements must be proven for application of instrumentality doctrine, in order to make controlling parties responsible for debts of corporate Chapter 11 debtors: (1) control of debtors; (2) use of that control in order to commit fraud or worse, to perpetrate a violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of legal rights; and (3) injury or unjust loss proximately caused by that control and breach of duty.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Court authorizes creditors' committee to pursue claims retroactively.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Carter-Jones Lumber Co. v. Dixie Distributing Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: Landowner sued corporation and its sole shareholder under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) to recover costs expended in cleanup of hazardous waste. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, Edmund A. Sargus, Jr., J., imposed several liability on defendants as arrangers for disposal. Defendants appealed and landowner cross-appealed. The Court of Appeals, Siler, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court's determination that defendants intended to arrange for disposal of hazardous waste, so as to be liable for response costs under CERCLA, was not clearly erroneous; (2) third party defense was unavailable to defendants; (3) system of cost apportionment under CERCLA is not unconstitutionally vague; (4) individual defendant was properly held liable; and (5) liability of corporation and individual defendant did not have to be several as a matter of law. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Altman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under New York law, party that seeks to pierce corporate veil must establish that shareholders, through their domination, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party, such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. Creditors established requisite cause for appointing Chapter 11 trustee.

Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Current owner of contaminated site could not bring cost recovery action under CERCLA.

Title: Bob's Beverage, Inc. v. ACME, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when (1) control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Current owner of contaminated site could not bring cost recovery action under CERCLA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Obras Civiles, S.A. v. ADM Securities, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Plaintiff may pierce corporate veil and defeat limited liability otherwise enjoyed by shareholder where: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporations cease to exist, and (2) adherence to fiction of separate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Construction company brought breach of contract and fiduciary duty action against investment company and its parent company, seeking return of solvency deposit made into real estate developer's investment account. On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Gettleman, J., held that: (1) Arizona law governed agency and contract interpretation issues; (2) fact issues precluded summary judgment on claims of apparent authority, piercing corporate veil, and interpretation of contract; but (3) no fiduciary relationship existed between construction company and investment company. Motion granted in part, and denied in part.

Title: Capsavage v. Esser
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Rule that corporate shareholders enjoy limited liability is not absolute; an exception will be made to metaphorically "pierce the corporate veil" and thus disregard the corporate entity and attach liability to shareholders where the corporation's affairs are organized, controlled and conducted so that the corporation has no separate existence of its own and is the mere instrumentality of the shareholders and the corporate form is used to evade an obligation, to gain an unjust advantage or to commit an injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder who had no direct involvement in yacht purchase contract was not liable for breach.

Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced when the corporate affiliation is conceived or used to perpetuate fraud or injustice or accomplish some unlawful purpose.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: BioCore, Inc. v. Khosrowshahi
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, courts will utilize the doctrine of "alter ego" to disregard the corporate entity and hold an individual responsible for those acts done knowingly and intentionally in the name of the corporation, when an individual uses a corporate entity merely as an instrumentality to conduct her own business, resulting in fraud or injustice on third parties who deal with the corporation.
Document Preview: Corporation producing medical chemicals, with its principal office in Kansas, sued former officer in federal district court for the Southern District of New York, alleging various tort and contract claims. Following transfer to federal district court in Kansas, former officer counterclaimed. Summary judgment motions were made. The District Court, Vratil, J., held that: (1) Kansas statute governing suit against shareholders following unsatisfied judgment against corporation did not apply to suit seeking piercing of corporate veil; (2) there was personal jurisdiction over Kansas citizen, who was chief executive officer of employer, under New York long-arm statute, as required for court to have jurisdiction over suit commenced in federal court in New York and transferred to federal court in Kansas; (3) exercise of personal jurisdiction was consistent with due process; (4) fact question whether corporations amenable to personal jurisdiction in New York were alter ego of another Kansas...

Title: Laird v. Capital Cities/ABC, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Corporate entities are presumed to have separate existences, and the corporate form will be disregarded only when the ends of justice require this result.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Parent corporation was not liable for discrimination perpetrated against employee of subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Maxx Race Cards, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division.
Headnote: North Carolina applies instrumentality rule to decide whether corporate veil should be pierced, under which the following three elements must be present for piercing to occur: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of corporate policy and business practice with respect to transactions attacked, such that corporate entity as to these transactions had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or to engage dishonest and unjust act contrary to plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Officers and directors did not owe fiduciary duty to corporate creditors.

Title: Johnson v. Exclusive Properties Unlimited
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: As a matter of public policy, corporations are separate legal entities with limited liability; as such, courts are generally reluctant to disregard the legal entity and will cautiously do so only when necessary to promote justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil piercing doctrine did not require a finding of fraud or illegality.

Title: Johnson v. Exclusive Properties Unlimited
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Court may pierce the corporate veil when equity so demands, and may disregard the corporate entity when used to cover fraud or illegality, or to justify a wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil piercing doctrine did not require a finding of fraud or illegality.

Title: Johnson v. Exclusive Properties Unlimited
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Before a court may pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must establish that: (1) the defendant abused the privilege of a separate corporate identity; and (2) an unjust or inequitable result would occur if the court recognized the separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil piercing doctrine did not require a finding of fraud or illegality.

Title: Johnson v. Exclusive Properties Unlimited

Headnote: Second prong of the veil piercing doctrine, that an unjust or inequitable result would occur if the court recognized the separate corporate existence, did not require a finding of fraud or illegality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil piercing doctrine did not require a finding of fraud or illegality.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: AT & T Global Information Solutions Co. v. Union Tank Car Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the requirement for piercing the corporate veil that control over a corporation was exercised to commit fraud or an illegal act does not require fraud in the formation of the corporation, but instead allows the corporate veil to be pierced when inequitable or unfair consequences have resulted.
Document Preview: Potentially responsible parties (PRPs) who entered consent order with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) concerning cleanup of solvent reclamation site brought contribution action under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) against subsidiary and grandparent corporations concerning alleged disposal of subsidiary's waste at site. Title: Townley v. Emerson Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Monroe County, New York.
Headnote: On occasion, courts will disregard the separate legal personality of corporation, and assign liability to its owners where necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity; however, such liability can never be predicated solely upon fact of a parent corporation's ownership of a controlling interest in shares of its subsidiary, and at the very least, there must be direct intervention by parent in management of subsidiary to such an extent that subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors, and officers are completely ignored.

Title: Shapiro, Lifschitz & Schram, P.C. v. Hazard

Headnote: Individuals or other entities may be held liable for the activities of a corporation when it is demonstrated that the corporation is not only controlled by those persons who are alleged alter egos of the corporation, but also that the separateness of the persons and the corporation has ceased and an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Motion to dismiss for lack of...

Title: People v. V & M Industries, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, there must be:(1) such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) circumstances which exist such that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported piercing of corporate veil as to corporate polluter.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: George Hyman Const. Co. v. Gateman
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, disregard of a corporate entity should occur only in rare particular situations to prevent gross inequity.
Document Preview: General contractor brought action against demolition subcontractor, which did not pay its vendors, and subcontractor's shareholders. Shareholders filed counterclaim for unfair and deceptive trade practices. The District Court, Saris, J., held that: (1) shareholders could not be held liable for corporate debts by virtue of piercing the corporate veil; (2) general contractor failed to state claim for fraud; (3) shareholders' conduct in transferring money from subcontractor to related corporation was not an unfair and deceptive business practice; and (4) general contractor's suit was not baseless, so as to constitute an unfair and deceptive trade practice. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Lorenz v. Beltio, Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Requirements for finding alter ego and piercing the corporate veil are: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego; (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other; and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Landlords brought action against tenant for a declaratory judgment that lease for motel property was terminated and seeking damages for waste committed on property. Title: Browning-Ferris Industries of Illinois, Inc. v. Ter Maat
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, when factors for determining whether to disregard a corporate entity are coupled with some element of injustice or fundamental unfairness, the corporation will be considered as an aggregate of persons both in equity and law, and its officers, directors and shareholders will be held liable for the corporation's obligations.
Document Preview: Former landfill operator brought action against subsequent corporate landfill operator, subsequent corporate transporter, and officer of subsequent operator and transporter under Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA) and Declaratory Judgment Act, seeking monetary damages for past and future costs incurred to respond to environmental contamination at landfill. The District Court, Reinhard, J., held that: (1) transporter was directly liable as operator; (2) officer was not individually liable under CERCLA as operator, pursuant to state veil-piercing theory; (3) affidavit of former operator's employee concerning type of waste hauled to landfill was admissible as nonhearsay admission by party opponent; (4) oversight costs of Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Illinois Environmental Protection Agency (IEPA) were recoverable under CERCLA; (5) subsequent operator, transporter, and site owners were responsible for costs of emergency removal...
