Title: American Institute of Certified Public Accountants v. Affinity Card, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Massachusetts, corporate veil will be pierced only if it is necessary to do so in order to prevent a gross inequity.
Document Preview: In suit for breach of contract, defendant corporation moved to vacate default judgment. The District Court, Scheindlin, J., held that: (1) assistant vice president of corporation separate from and unaffiliated with defendant, but sharing office and having common president and partial owner, was not sufficiently integrated with defendant to allow the inference that he had authority to receive service of process for defendant; (2) fact that president of defendant actually received summons and complaint on the very same day was not sufficient to cure defective service; (3) service on separate corporation would not be deemed to constitute effective service on defendant on ground that they were both virtual alter egos of person who was president and part owner of each, under Massachusetts law; (4) service was ineffective under New York law, where service was on a non-employee who made no representations as to authorization to receive service; (5) service was also...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Rebh v. Rotterdam Ventures Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced when a shareholder has exercised complete domination over the affairs of a corporation, with respect to the transaction being assailed, and used that control to commit a fraud or wrong against a third party, to the latter's detriment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. There were fact issues precluding summary judgment in suit to pierce corporate veil to collect subsidiary's debt from parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Love v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Corporate fiction will be disregarded to prevent the use of the corporate entity as a cloak for fraud or illegality or to work an injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporation Veil. Evidence supported finding of necessity to pierce the corporate veil to impose individual liability for penalties and well-plugging costs involving oil and gas leases.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Miranda v. Smyrna Building Corp.
Court: Civil Court, City of New York, Richmond County.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, there must be a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Vendor breached its contract with purchasers by failing to provide tax abatements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sharon Towers, Inc. v. Bank Leumi Trust Co. of New York
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To justify piercing the corporate veil, it is not enough to show that the individual owned a majority interest in the corporation, either directly or indirectly; there must also be proof that the individual completely dominated the corporation, such that it was a mere device to further his personal business, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or a wrong against the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Venue. Proper venue for corporation's proceeding to determine adverse claims to funds held by bank was county in which bank maintained office and transacted business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Chisholm v. Foothill Capital Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, separate existence of corporation will be disregarded and veil of limited liability will be pierced if: (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual, or other corporation, no longer exist and (2) situation is such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against her former employer, related corporation, former supervisor and former co-worker, claiming sex discrimination and retaliation in violation of Title VII of Civil Rights Act of 1964, wage disparity in violation of Title VII and Equal Pay Act (EPA), defamation and invasion of privacy. Defendants moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Gettleman, J., held that: (1) former employer and related corporation were not single employer for purposes of employment discrimination liability; (2) former employee failed to show that she was constructively discharged in violation of Title VII; (3) genuine issue of material fact precluded summary judgment on the EPA and Title VII wage claims; (4) various actions identified by former employee were not adverse employment actions for purposes of Title VII retaliation claim; (5) former employee lacked admissible evidence to establish defamation claim; and (6) co-worker's disclosure of fact that former...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: White v. Midwest Office Technology, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: The alter ego theory for piercing the corporate veil is founded in equity and permits the court to pierce the veil when the court must prevent fraud, illegality or injustice, or when recognition of the corporate entity would defeat public policy or shield someone from liability from a crime.
Document Preview: Employee brought action against her employer, its owner, and its general manager, asserting claims of sexual harassment and retaliation in violation of the Kansas Act Against Discrimination (KAAD) and Title VII, and state common-law claims for tort of outrage, tort of retaliation for filing a workers' compensation claim and breach of implied employment contract. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: White v. Midwest Office Technology, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: The federal common law doctrine of piercing the corporate veil under an alter ego theory can best be described by a two-part test: (1) whether there was such a unity of interest and lack of respect given to the separate identity of the corporation by its shareholders that the personalities and assets of the corporation and the individual are indistinct, and (2) whether adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations.
Document Preview: Employee brought action against her employer, its owner, and its general manager, asserting claims of sexual harassment and retaliation in violation of the Kansas Act Against Discrimination (KAAD) and Title VII, and state common-law claims for tort of outrage, tort of retaliation for filing a workers' compensation claim and breach of implied employment contract. On defendants' motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Saffels, J., held that: (1) employee made sufficient showing of continuing course of conduct to avoid summary judgment as to incidents that allegedly occurred prior to Title VII's 300day limitations period; (2) manager's alleged conduct was not sufficiently severe or pervasive to objectively alter terms, conditions or privilege of employee's employment; (3) employee failed to establish a claim of constructive discharge; (4) employee failed to establish a claim of retaliatory discharge; (5) employee failed to establish that she was subjected to disparate...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Steadfast Ins. Co., Inc. v. Auto Marketing Network, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under California law, two requirements for applying the alter ego doctrine for piercing corporate veil are that (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and the individual or organization controlling it that their separate personalities no longer exist, and (2) failure to disregard the corporate entity would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Collateral protection insurer brought action against insured lender and its parent corporation for declaratory judgment and damages based on theories of promissory fraud, insurance fraud, and piercing of corporate veil. Lender and parent corporation moved to dismiss. The District Court, Aspen, Chief Judge., held that: (1) insurer's complaint against insured lender and buyer of loans alleged actionable scheme of promissory fraud and alleged insurance fraud; (2) insurer's complaint against insured lender satisfied particularity requirement for pleading fraud; and (3) insurer adequately pleaded liability of insured lender's parent corporation on alter ego theory for piercing corporate veil. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Greenberg v. Commonwealth ex rel. Atty. Gen. of Virginia
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Disregarding the corporate entity is usually warranted if shareholder sought to be held personally liable has controlled or used corporation to evade personal obligation, to perpetrate fraud or crime, to commit injustice, or to gain unfair advantage.
Document Preview: Commonwealth brought suit against check cashing corporation, alleging it made loans in amounts and at interest rates in violation of Consumer Finance Act (CFA).  The Circuit Court found that corporation's cash advance services violated CFA, enjoined corporation from violating CFA, and entered judgment for Commonwealth as trustee for affected borrowers.  Commonwealth then sought restitution from chairman of board and majority shareholder of corporation of amounts corporation received from borrowers in violation of CFA.  The Circuit Court, City of Richmond, Theodore J. Markow, J., issued judgment imposing personal liability on chairman, and chairman appealed.  The Supreme Court, Kinser, J., held that: (1) CFA permitted recovery of restitution only from lender, not from chairman, and (2) piercing corporate veil to impose personal liability on chairman was not justified. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and final judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Smith v. Washington Sheraton Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, acts and obligations of corporate entity will not be recognized as those of particular person until party seeking to disregard corporate entity has proved by affirmative evidence that there is unity of ownership and interest and use of corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: Plaintiff injured when she fell from ramp leading from parking garage into hotel lobby brought diversity action against various defendants.  The United States District Court for the District of Columbia, Johnson, J., granted judgment as matter of law for all but one defendant, which was found negligent by jury, and that defendant appealed.  Plaintiff cross-appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Randolph, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) whether one dismissed defendant corporation exercised ownership or control over ramp leading from parking garage into hotel lobby was question for jury; (2) corporation found negligent should have been granted judgment as matter of law, but proper remedy was new trial; (3) pretrial order relieved plaintiff of burden of proving ownership or control; (4) parent corporation of other defendants was not liable absent attempt to pierce corporate veil; and (5) plaintiff was not contributorily negligent as matter of law. Affirmed in part,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bitar v. Wakim
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Corporate structure will be disregarded when equities are compelling, and in such cases, corporate veil is pierced and shareholders are held liable for acts of corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Equities and justice did not warrant reverse piercing of corporate veil in order for premises owner to invoke exclusive remedy provision of Workers' Disability Compensation Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bitar v. Wakim
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Courts will pierce the corporate veil, where honoring corporate structure would subvert justice or perpetuate fraud based on consideration of facts and equities of case.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Equities and justice did not warrant reverse piercing of corporate veil in order for premises owner to invoke exclusive remedy provision of Workers' Disability Compensation Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. Fidelity & Guar. Co., Inc. v. Paul Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Corporate entity can be disregarded where corporate arrangement was sham; corporation over-extended its privileges in use of corporate form to defeat justice or to evade statutory, contractual, or tort liability; or principals otherwise abused and disregarded corporate form.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Insured's failure to pay premiums did not relieve agent of liability for negligent misrepresentation that insured qualified for coverage through assigned risk pool.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Middleton v. Parish of Jefferson
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is a flexible doctrine that can be used in any situation in which separate personality of corporation appears to be blocking a just result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President and corporation were the same party for purposes of res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Harrison v. NBD Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff must demonstrate complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue and that such domination was used to commit the wrong that injured the plaintiff.
Document Preview: Consumer who incurred debt for home study course brought putative class action against creditor-correspondence school and collection agency, alleging that demand letter sent by agency violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA).  Defendants moved for partial dismissal for failure to state a claim and consumer moved for leave to amend complaint, if necessary.  The District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) allegations in complaint were inadequate to establish that school was a debt collector subject to liability under FDCPA, and (2) consumer was entitled to amend complaint. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hutchison v. Anderson
Court: Court of Appeals of Idaho.
Headnote: Court may disregard corporate entity if there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and there is showing that, if acts are treated as those of corporation, an inequitable result will follow or that it would sanction fraud or promote injustice. I.C. § 30–1–25 (Repealed).

Barry Wood, J., entered judgment for former employees, awarding back wages, treble damages, prejudgment interest, costs, and attorney fees. President and corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Perry, J., held that: (1) evidence supported piercing corporate veil to find president personally liable; (2) evidence supported finding that first employee worked one month longer than claimed by employer, and that his suit for unpaid wages was filed within six-month statute of limitations; (3) evidence supported finding that employment agreement was hourly; (4) employer was not entitled to credit for insurance benefits and horses provided to employees as bonus; (5) district court did not award employees credit for hours they did not work; but (6) wage claim statute was exclusive section under which attorney fees could be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Keams v. Tempe Technical Institute, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: Under Arizona law, undercapitalization of corporation is important factor in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, but not absolute ground in absence of fraud or injustice to aggrieved parties.

Title: Keams v. Tempe Technical Institute, Inc.

Headnote: Under Arizona law, those seeking to pierce corporate veil on ground of undercapitalization must show that financial setup of corporation is only sham and causes injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Thrift Drug, Inc. v. Universal Prescription Adm'rs
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, it must be shown (i) that owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue; and (ii) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: Pharmacy sued prescription benefits plan administrator and administrator's sole shareholder for breach of contract, alleging that defendants failed to reimburse pharmacy for dispensed prescriptions.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 890 F.Supp. 319, granted summary judgment for pharmacy, and held that pharmacy could pierce administrator's corporate veil to reach shareholder's personal assets. Administrator and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) district court's findings with respect to piercing of corporate veil were insufficient; (2) pharmacy showed that it timely submitted claims to administrator; and (3) ERISA did not preempt action. Affirmed in part, vacated and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dean v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, individual will be deemed to be alter ego of corporation when: (1) individual completely dominates and controls finances, policy and business practice of other corporation; (2) such control was for improper purpose such as fraud or wrong, or unjust act in contravention of third parties' legal rights; and (3) alter ego's control of corporation caused injury to third party.
Document Preview: Trustees brought action asserting that Internal Revenue Service (IRS) made wrongful levy on trust assets. The District Court, Laughrey, J., held that irrevocable trust was not alter ego of delinquent taxpayers and, therefore, IRS wrongfully levied on trust assets. Ordered Accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Goya Foods, Inc. v. Unanue-Casal
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: In order for corporate veil piercing to be allowed, under New York law, there must be showing that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor sued judgement debtor, seeking to enforce judgment.  The District Court, Fuste, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would be pierced to allow creditor to reach assets of corporation over which debtor was equitable owner, and (2) judgment could be satisfied out of assets of wife. Judgment for creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Circle Land and Cattle Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Before Kansas court will grant creditor's request to pierce corporate veil, creditor must show that shareholder conducted his or her personal business through corporate entity by fraud, injustice, or wrongdoing, which was damaging to creditor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Veil-piercing factors alleged by creditor did not warrant substantive consolidation of Chapter 11 debtor with alleged corporate alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Desiderio
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, Pennsylvania courts are basically concerned with determining if equity requires that shareholders' traditional insulation from personal liability be disregarded and with ascertaining if corporate form is a sham, constituting a facade for operations of dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: Discharge. Even if broker stood in fiduciary capacity to insurance company, this would not support nondischargeability judgment against broker's president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Payroll Exp. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, court will apply equitable alter ego doctrine to disregard corporate form and impose liability on individual stockholder: (1) when stockholders' disregard of corporate entity makes corporation a mere instrumentality for transaction of their own affairs; (2) when there is such a unity of interest and ownership between corporation and stockholders that the separate personalities of corporation and stockholders no longer exist; and (3) when adherence to doctrine of the corporate entity would promote injustice or protect fraud.
Document Preview: Insurance - Prior losses in excess of $2.3 million that insured failed to disclose on its application for insurance were material as matter of law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Commonwealth Aluminum Corp. v. Baldwin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is permissible to disregard separate corporate entities, that is, to pierce a corporate veil, in rare particular situations in order to prevent gross inequity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Main, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, piercing of corporate veil is narrow exception to general rule of corporate autonomy; corporate veil will be pierced only when it is necessary to avoid injustice to another party, when it is necessary to prevent injustice, illegality or fraud, or when recognizing the corporate entity would result in violation of public policy or protect someone from liability for crime.
Document Preview: Business Organizations. Corporate veil could not be pierced, so as to bring debtor-corporations' assets into bankruptcy estate of individual Chapter 7 debtor.

Title: Chan v. Society Expeditions, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.

Title: Ditty v. CheckRite, Ltd., Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Freeman v. Complex Computing Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff must prove that owner has exercised such control that corporation has become mere instrumentality of owner, which is real actor, such control has been used to commit fraud or other wrong, and fraud or wrong results in unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.

The Court of Appeals, Miner, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) Court of Appeals had jurisdiction over cross-appeal; (2) Court of Appeals would exercise jurisdiction over appeal under doctrine of pendent appellate jurisdiction; (3) student was equitable owner of company who...

Title: Freeman v. Complex Computing Co., Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Trans-World Intern., Inc. v. Smith-Hemion Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, basic rule of alter ego theory requires court to find such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist and that adherence to fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, promote fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Production company sued musical performers in family group and performers' corporation, alleging promissory estoppel, fraud, and alter ego claims arising out of cancelled televised performance.  After mistrial, plaintiff dismissed fraud claim and parties submitted claims to court based on record created during trial.  The District Court, Laughlin E. Waters, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) production company failed to establish promissory estoppel claim against performer who stated intent to appear on show; (2) dismissal of fraud claim did not preclude alter ego claims; and (3) performers were not alter egos of corporation. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kindle Bldg. Co. v. Ford Motor Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Although no precise standard exists to pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must show that parent corporation: (1) dominates and controls subsidiary so that it has no mind, will or existence of its own; (2) used that domination to commit fraud, wrong, or other dishonest or unjust acts; and (3) injured plaintiff.
Document Preview: Lessor brought action against parent corporation of dissolved corporate lessee, alleging damages caused when lessee installed defective underground storage tank on lessor's property. Parent moved for summary judgment, and lessor moved to amend complaint. The District Court, Carr, J., held that: (1) allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, and (2) court would not grant lessor's motion for leave to amend complaint to include statutory charges. Judgment as ordered. Affirmed,  F.3d .

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Stoebner v. Lingenfelter
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, deciding whether to allow corporate veil to be pierced requires court, first, to analyze whether corporation functioned as mere instrumentality of principals the party is attempting to reach by piercing corporate veil, and, second, to determine whether injustice or fundamental unfairness would occur if corporate veil were left intact.
Document Preview: Corporations. In action by Chapter 7 trustee to avoid fraudulent transfers, reverse piercing of debtor's corporate veil was not warranted to show that debtor received value for debtor's payments to transferee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Eagle Pacific Ins. Co. v. Christensen Motor Yacht Corp.

Headnote: Doctrine of corporate disregard will not apply unless it is necessary and required to prevent unjustified loss to injured party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporations. Corporation that purchased debtor's assets was liable for debts of debtor under successor liability.

Title: Shared Communications Services of 1800-80 JFK Blvd. Inc. v. Bell Atlantic Properties Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Barton v. Moore
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: In deciding whether shareholder can be liable for corporate obligations on veil-piercing theory, court employs two-pronged test that focuses first on shareholder's relationship to corporation and then on whether veil piercing is necessary to avoid injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: Lenders brought suit to recover from corporation and corporate shareholders, on alter ego and direct liability theory, for alleged breach of loan agreement, and defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state claim on which relief could be granted.  The District Court, Allan R. Markert, J., granted defendants' motion, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Kalitowski, J., 1996 WL 33099, reversed, and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Gardebring, J., held that: (1) allegations in lenders' complaint were sufficient to state veil-piercing claim, and (2) statute specifically limiting the interest rate of loans for business or agricultural purposes provided exclusive remedy for business borrowers who obtained loans found to be usurious under statute. Judgment of Court of Appeals, affirmed; case remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Robbins v. Blecher
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Under alter ego doctrine, where corporation is used by individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, court may disregard corporate entity and treat corporation's acts as if they were done by persons actually controlling corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Malicious Prosecution. Voluntary dismissal of action was not favorable termination on merits supporting subsequent malicious prosecution action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Robbins v. Blecher
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: In general, requirements for applying alter ego doctrine are that there is such unity of interest and ownership between corporation and individual or organization controlling it that their separate personalities no longer exist, and that failure to disregard corporate entity would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS - Malicious Prosecution. Voluntary dismissal of action was not favorable termination on merits supporting subsequent malicious prosecution action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Robbins v. Blecher
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is applicable where innocent party attacks corporate form as injury to that party's interests; issue is not so much whether corporate entity should be disregarded for all purposes or whether its very purpose was to defraud innocent party, as it is whether in particular case presented, justice and equity can best be accomplished and fraud and unfairness defeated by disregarding distinct entity of corporate form.
Document Preview: TORTS - Malicious Prosecution. Voluntary dismissal of action was not favorable termination on merits supporting subsequent malicious prosecution action.

Headnote: Corporate veils exist for a reason under Colorado law, and should be pierced only reluctantly and cautiously, as law permits incorporation of businesses for very purpose of isolating liabilities among separate entities; however, when corporate structure is used so improperly that continued recognition of corporation as separate legal entity would be unfair, corporate entity may be disregarded and corporate principals held liable for corporation's actions.

Title: Dieter Engineering Services, Inc. v. Parkland Development, Inc.

Title: Dieter Engineering Services, Inc. v. Parkland Development, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: In case involving alleged breach of contract, to pierce corporate veil in order to hold shareholders actively participating in operation of business personally liable for such breach to party who entered into contract with corporation, there is normally two-prong test: (1) there must be such unity of interest in ownership that separate personalities of corporation and of individual shareholders no longer exist (disregard of formality as requirement) and (2) inequitable result would occur if acts are treated as those of corporation alone (fairness requirement).

Title: McClaran v. Plastic Industries, Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc. Dealerships Relations Litigation

Title: Wilson v. Friedberg

Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Anderson, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Condon, Master-in-equity, found for plaintiffs and awarded damages, and defendants appealed. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wilson v. Friedberg
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: In proving fundamental unfairness for purposes of piercing corporate veil, plaintiff must establish that defendant was aware of plaintiff's claim against corporation and acted in self-serving manner in disregard of that claim; essence of fairness test is simply that individual businessperson cannot be allowed to hide from normal consequences of carefree entrepreneuring by doing so through corporate shell.

Title: In re Terrific Seafoods, Inc.

Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts will pierce the corporate veil in two broad situations: to prevent fraud or other wrong, or where parent dominates and controls a subsidiary.
Document Preview: Salesperson for computer software company brought action against company, successor corporation, and university student, who developed computer software but was prohibited by university policy from serving as officer, director or stockholder in a corporation marketing software and thus had a corporation organized to get around policy, alleging breach of contract and tortious interference with contract. Salesperson moved to compel arbitration. The District Court, Kaplan, J., held that: (1) salesperson's commencement of breach of contract action was not a default in proceeding with arbitration and did not preclude him from seeking order compelling arbitration; (2) salesperson did not waive right to arbitrate by commencing action; (3) claim against university student was arbitrable, although he was not a party to any arbitration clause; and (4) successor corporation was not subject to arbitration agreement. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hart v. Steel Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In determining whether party seeking to pierce corporate veil has met its burden of showing that corporate form was abused, court is to consider whether evidence has been presented showing: undercapitalization, absence of corporate records; fraudulent representations by corporate shareholders or directors; use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegal activities; payment by corporation of individual obligations; commingling of assets and affairs; failure to observe required corporate formalities; or other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating corporate form.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Sale of business contract rescindable for fraud in inducement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Pope v. Professional Funding Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Although great caution should be exercised in disregarding or going behind corporate entity, it may be done when evidence shows that separate personalities of corporation and owners no longer exist; and to adhere to doctrine of corporate entity would promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporations. Funds commingling sustained piercing of corporation veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: ADO Finance, AG v. McDonnell Douglas Corp.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, to apply alter ego doctrine, court must determine that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individuals no longer exist and that failure to disregard corporation would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: In action arising out of sale of aircraft, alleged alter egos of buyer moved to dismiss counterclaim against them for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The District Court, Wardlaw, J., held that seller made prima facie showing of alter ego liability, whether Swiss, Liechtenstein, or California law governing piercing the corporate veil or imposition of alter ego liability applied. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Zimmerman v. Eagle Mtge. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded when: control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard corporate entity; and injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Burden of proof rests on employer to show that deductions from employee's paycheck for expenses are valid and proper.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Jacobson v. Buffalo Rock Shooters Supply Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.

Document Preview: Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiffs failed to make substantial showing necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sims v. Western Waste Industries
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Purpose in disregarding the corporate fiction is to prevent use of the corporate entity as cloak for fraud or illegality or to work injustice and that purpose should not be thwarted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. Wallace
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded in interest of public convenience, fairness and equity, but courts generally limit veil piercing to situations in which corporate subsidiary is established to perpetrate fraud, its shareholders drain corporation's assets, or subsidiary is totally dominated and controlled by parent corporation as its business conduit or alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kregos v. Latest Line, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: "Identity rule" for disregarding corporate entity under Connecticut law applies when plaintiff shows such unity of interest and ownership that independence of corporation had in effect ceased or had never begun, and that adherence to fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity.
Document Preview: Writer of daily newspaper feature column brought suit against corporation which contracted with him to write the column, and the sole officers, directors and shareholders of the corporation, alleging breach of contract, and against syndicator of the column, alleging tortious interference with contract.  On individual defendant's and syndicator's motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) fact questions precluded summary judgment on claim seeking to pierce corporate veil to hold individual defendants personally liable for acts of their corporation, but (2) there was no evidence to support crucial elements of writer's tortious interference claim against syndicator. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Joiner v. Ryder System Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Pursuant to Illinois "alter ego doctrine," courts will pierce corporate veil only when there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of the corporations no longer exist, and the circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporation existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Worker brought strict products liability and negligence action to recover for injuries sustained when he attempted to remove skids located at rear of automobile transport trailer.  Parent company of trailer's manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) parent company did not exert improper control over subsidiaries so as to support argument that parent was alter ego of trailer manufacturer; (2) parent company did not hold itself out as manufacturer of trailer, for purposes of liability under apparent manufacturer doctrine; and (3) assuming parent company was aware prior to injuries in question that trailer was unsafe, parent did not have duty to order subsidiary to redesign trailer. Motion for summary judgment allowed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Joiner v. Ryder System Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: In order to satisfy the "promote injustice" prong of test for disregarding separate identities of corporations, there must be some element of unfairness, something akin to fraud or deception, or the existence of a compelling public interest.
Document Preview: Worker brought strict products liability and negligence action to recover for injuries sustained when he attempted to remove skids located at rear of automobile transport trailer.  Parent company of trailer's manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) parent company did not exert improper control over subsidiaries so as to support argument that parent was alter ego of trailer manufacturer; (2) parent company did not hold itself out as manufacturer of trailer, for purposes of liability under apparent manufacturer doctrine; and (3) assuming parent company was aware prior to injuries in question that trailer was unsafe, parent did not have duty to order subsidiary to redesign trailer. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kuempel Serv., Inc. v. Zofko
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, First District, Hamilton County.
Headnote: General criteria considered by court in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are whether persons upon whom liability is to be imposed exercised such complete domination and control over corporation that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, whether such dominance and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or any dishonest or unjust act, and whether injury or unjust loss to plaintiff was result of such control and wrong.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Insufficiency of assets upon dissolution does not establish corporation was undercapitalized, for alter ego purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Janos v. Murduck
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: In order for plaintiff to pierce veil of corporate form and hold corporate shareholder personally accountable, plaintiff must demonstrate (1) control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation did not have separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss must have resulted from control and wrongful conduct.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Fact question existed as to whether corporate veil of window seller should be pierced.

Title: Wiencek v. Atcole Co., Inc.

Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Issues of fact were for jury in action to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Olen v. Phelps
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Shareholder's act will be treated as corporate act and existence of corporation as entity apart from actual persons comprising it will be disregarded, if corporate affairs are organized, controlled and conducted so that corporation has no separate existence of its own and is mere instrumentality of shareholder and corporate form is used to evade obligation, to gain unjust advantage or to commit injustice.
Document Preview: Garnishment. Reverse veil-piercing applied to permit judgment creditor of sole shareholder of accounting firm to garnish accounting firm office building to satisfy judgment against sole shareholder.

Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Ceiling Wall Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil, under Illinois law, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Suit was brought by union against contractors alleging violation of Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA), Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA) and Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO).  Motions to dismiss were made.  The District Court, Nordberg, J., held that: (1) cause of action had been stated for piercing of corporate veil, under Illinois law; (2) National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) did not preempt RICO counts; and (3) Labor-Management Relations Act did preempt RICO. Motions to dismiss denied in part, granted in part.

Title: Tung v. Briant Park Homes, Inc.

Title: Dumas v. InfoSafe Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must prove element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if acts of corporation are not regarded as acts of the individuals; to prove fundamental unfairness, plaintiff must establish that defendant was aware of plaintiff's claim against corporation and, thereafter, acted in self-serving manner with regard to property of the corporation and in disregard of plaintiff's claim in the property.
Document Preview: Employee brought suit against his employer and its president and sole shareholder seeking unpaid wages.  The Circuit Court, Charleston County, James B. Stephen, Special Judge, awarded treble damages against corporation, but refused to hold the president personally liable.  Employee appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Hearn, J., held that: (1) necessary elements were present for piercing the corporate veil, and (2) president was individually liable under Payment of Wages Act. Reversed and remanded.

Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.

Title: MCI Telecommunications Corp. v. O'Brien Marketing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under federal common-law alter ego rule, general rule is that corporate entity may be disregarded in the interests of public convenience, fairness, and equity; in applying this rule, federal courts will look closely at purpose of federal statute involved to determine whether statute places importance on corporate form, an inquiry that usually gives less respect to corporate form than does strict common-law alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Long-distance telephone company brought action against corporate customer, which was telemarketer, to recover unpaid charges for interstate telecommunication services provided to customer.  After entry of judgment for company and award of attorney fees to company, company moved to institute proceedings supplementary, and order was issued requiring corporation to show cause why it should not be impleaded as party, as alter ego of customer.  Upon corporation's failure to respond to show cause order, corporation was impleaded as party.  The District Court, Highsmith, J., held that: (1) federal law, rather than state law, applied to issue of piercing the corporate veil, and (2) piercing of the corporate veil of customer was appropriate and, thus, corporation was liable, as alter ego of customer, for final judgment for unpaid charges and for attorney fees and costs. Ordered accordingly.

Document Preview: Arkansas-based buyer of wood veneer, for use in custom decoration of aircraft, brought breach of contract and breach of warranty suit against North Carolina seller, and French manufacturer which was parent of seller.  Manufacturer moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Eliason, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) material issues of fact, precluding summary judgment, existed as to whether corporate veil could be pierced so as to allow claims to be asserted against manufacturer; (2) choice of law provisions contained in both seller's invoice and buyer's order confirmation were nonbinding; (3) under North Carolina choice of law rule Arkansas law was applicable to contract; and (4) suit for breach of warranty was maintainable against manufacturer under Arkansas law, as privity of contract was not required. Motion denied.

Title: Dassault Falcon Jet Corp. v. Oberflex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina, ,Durham Division..
Headnote: Wrong or injustice for which corporate veil may be pierced, under North Carolina law, need not include fraud; it is sufficient that actions show ulterior purpose to benefit person in control in way not possible or legal without misuse of controlled corporation.
Document Preview: Arkansas-based buyer of wood veneer, for use in custom decoration of aircraft, brought breach of contract and breach of warranty suit against North Carolina seller, and French manufacturer which was parent of seller.  Manufacturer moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Eliason, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) material issues of fact, precluding summary judgment, existed as to whether corporate veil could be pierced so as to allow claims to be asserted against manufacturer; (2) choice of law provisions contained in both seller's invoice and buyer's order confirmation were nonbinding; (3) under North Carolina choice of law rule Arkansas law was applicable to contract; and (4) suit for breach of warranty was maintainable against manufacturer under Arkansas law, as privity of contract was not required. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Seasword v. Hilti, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities will be respected, and law presumes that absent some abuse of corporate form, parent and subsidiary corporations are separate and distinct entities; presumption, often referred to as "corporate veil," may be pierced only where otherwise separate corporate existence has been used to subvert justice or cause result that is contrary to some other clearly overriding public policy, and subsidiary must become mere instrumentality of parent before its separate corporate existence will be disregarded.
Document Preview: Corporations. Michigan declines to adopt apparent manufacturer doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Matter of New Center Hosp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, separate corporate identities will be respected, and corporate veils will be pierced only to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Consolidation. order substantively consolidating nondebtor entities into Chapter 11 estate on alter ego theory should not have been entered nunc pro tunc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ford Motor Credit Co. v. Moore
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Corporate entity will be disregarded when used to cover fraud or illegality or to justify a wrong.
Document Preview: Assignee of lessor's rights under equipment lease and guaranty sued to recover from guarantors after equipment lessee defaulted and filed for bankruptcy relief.  From entry of summary judgment against guarantors on third-party claim, appeal was taken, and the Supreme Judicial Court, Dana J., 645 A.2d 626,affirmed in part, vacated in part and remanded.  On remand, the Superior Court, Cumberland County, Brodrick and Fritzsche, JJ., entered judgments in favor of plaintiff and of corporate shareholders named as third-party defendants, and guarantors appealed.  The Supreme Judicial Court, Wathen, C.J., held that: (1) Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) provision regarding equipment lessor's obligation to act in commercially reasonable manner in accepting tender of leased goods did not apply retroactively to equipment lease which was executed prior to statute's effective date; (2) waiver-of-rights provision in guaranty was not unenforceable as matter of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Tannahill v. Aunspach
Court: Court of Appeals of Iowa.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded under exceptional circumstances, resulting in personal liability for a shareholder; these circumstances include that of sham corporation serving no legitimate purpose used to perpetrate fraud or promote injustice; corporation's failure to follow corporate formalities is among the facts considered in making this determination.
Document Preview: Lessor of automobiles sued shareholder of lessee corporation, and subsequent purchaser of lessee's assets, for breach of oral rental agreement.  The District Court, Cerro Gordo County, Gilbert K. Bovard, J., determined that breach of oral rental agreement had occurred, and awarded damages to lessor, finding shareholder personally liable.  Shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Huitink, J., held that piercing of corporate veil was not supported by evidence where lessor prepared the documents, and president did not conceal the corporate principal, or represent that the leases were a personal undertaking. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Austin Powder Co. v. McCullough
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Where plaintiff can establish that owner of corporation exercised complete domination of corporation with respect to transaction in question and said domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff resulting in plaintiff's injury, corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Judgment. Creditor was entitled to pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State v. Easton
Court: Supreme Court, Albany County, New York.
Headnote: Broadly speaking, courts will disregard corporate form to pierce corporate veil, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or achieve equity.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Corporation could be held liable for judgment against nonshareholder controlling person.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bitar v. Wakim
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Generally separate entities will be respected, but doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is appropriate to invoke for the benefit of a shareholder where the equities are compelling.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Injured employee's negligence claim against sole shareholder of employer corporation barred by exclusivity rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Alberto v. Diversified Group, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to pierce corporate veil on alter ego theory, plaintiff must demonstrate misuse of corporate form or overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Homeowners could not pierce corporate veil on developer or alter ego theory to hold parent liable for developer's debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: McCabe v. Henpil, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, when there is such unity between corporation and individual that separateness of corporation has ceased and holding only corporation liable would result in injustice, court may hold shareholder liable for actions of corporation.
Document Preview: Employee brought state court action against employer and employer's subsidiary, alleging tort claims related to employee's work-related accident. Suit was removed to federal court.  On plaintiff's motion to remand, the District Court, Schell, Chief Judge, held that: (1) negligence and strict liability claims were not subject to Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) preemption; (2) intentional infliction of emotional distress and mental anguish claim related to employer's occupational injury and disease benefits plan; (3) defendants did not establish that benefit plan fell outside of workers' compensation exception to ERISA preemption; but (4) subsidiary was fraudulently joined to destroy diversity, and diversity jurisdiction existed. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Ankeny
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: California test for determining whether entity or individual is alter ego of corporation has two elements: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities no longer exist, and (2) that, if acts are treated as those of corporation alone, inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: Employments. because corporation and corporation's president were dual employers, employee could assert claim for indemnification against bankruptcy estates of both corporation and its president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Pel-Star Energy, Inc. v. U.S. Dept. of Energy
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Louisiana, Shreveport Division. .
Headnote: Corporate entity will not be recognized when to do so would work fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Corporate crude oil reseller and partial owner of reseller brought action seeking judicial review of Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) order finding owner personally liable, through piercing the corporate veil, for $4,663,852.89 in crude oil overcharges by reseller plus interest under crude oil antilayering regulations.  The District Court, Stagg, J., held that: (1) it would review order de novo, rather than under substantial evidence test; (2) Commission had jurisdiction to impose personal liability on owner for crude oil overcharges, despite fact that Commission was not Article III court; (3) federal law, rather than state law, governed its determination of propriety of Commission's decision to pierce the corporate veil; and (4) piercing of the corporate veil was improper. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Pel-Star Energy, Inc. v. U.S. Dept. of Energy
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Louisiana, Shreveport Division. .

The District Court, Stagg, J., held that: (1) it would review order de novo, rather than under substantial evidence test; (2) Commission had jurisdiction to impose personal liability on owner for crude oil overcharges, despite fact that Commission was not Article III court; (3) federal law, rather than state law, governed its determination of propriety of Commission's decision to pierce the corporate veil; and (4) piercing of the corporate veil was improper. Reversed.

Title: Dean Operations, Inc. v. One Seventy Associates
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Plaintiff raising corporate alter ego claim must show that allowing legal fiction of separate corporate structure would result in injustice toward plaintiff.
Document Preview: Parent corporation, which had purchased loan to partnership in which its subsidiary was managing partner, brought action to foreclose on loan. The Wyandotte District Court, Philip L. Sieve, J., granted partial summary judgment for other partner, finding that managing partner was alter ego of its parent.  The Court of Appeals granted parent's application for interlocutory appeal, and the Supreme Court granted parent's motion to transfer.  The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that parent was alter ego of subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dean Operations, Inc. v. One Seventy Associates
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded where it is used as mere subterfuge, as implement for fraud or illegality, or to work an injustice, or where necessary to achieve equity.
Document Preview: Parent corporation, which had purchased loan to partnership in which its subsidiary was managing partner, brought action to foreclose on loan. The Wyandotte District Court, Philip L. Sieve, J., granted partial summary judgment for other partner, finding that managing partner was alter ego of its parent.  The Court of Appeals granted parent's application for interlocutory appeal, and the Supreme Court granted parent's motion to transfer.  The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that parent was alter ego of subsidiary. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Coala, Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >

Title: Muroll Gesellschaft M.B.H. v. Tennessee Tape, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Middle Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: In an appropriate case and in furtherance of the ends of justice, a corporation and the individual or individuals owning all of its stock will be treated as identical.

Title: Mass v. McClenahan
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts are reluctant to disregard corporate entity, and generally, to justify piercing corporate veil plaintiff must show that owner exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Attorney, who was formerly employed by corporation as its attorney, president, and chief executive officer (CEO), sued corporation and its sole shareholder for race discrimination in contracts under §1981, conspiracy to violate civil rights under §1985, and breach of employment contract, and he brought conspiracy claim against companies owned by shareholder.  On defendants' motions for full or partial summary judgment, the District Court, Martin, J., held that: (1) §1981 extended by its terms to attorney-client relationship, and this did not impinge on corporation's First Amendment freedom of association; (2) allegations did not support inference of companies' participation in civil rights conspiracy; (3) allegations against corporation and shareholder did not satisfy conspiracy requirement for civil rights conspiracy claim; (4) fact questions as to attorney's compliance with Nevada professional...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Jack LaLanne Fitness Centers, Inc. v. Jimlar, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Before court may pierce corporate veil under New Jersey law, showing of fraud or injustice is required.
Document Preview: Tenants sought to preclude enforcement of retroactive rent adjustment and landlord filed counterclaims.  After five separately filed lawsuits were consolidated.  The District Court, Lifland, J., held that: (1) landlord's compulsory counterclaims were not barred in light of consolidation of actions, and (2) court would not pierce corporate veil of tenants' parent companies absent allegation of fraud or injustice. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Hoffman Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under Fourth Circuit's DeWitt test, element of injustice or fundamental unfairness must exist before corporate veil may be pierced, and court's conclusion to disregard the corporate entity may not rest on single factor but, rather, must involve number of such factors, which include: whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized; whether there was failure to observe corporate formalities; whether there was nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, siphoning of corporation's funds by dominant stockholder, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, or absence of corporate records; and whether corporation was merely facade for operations of the dominant stockholder.
Document Preview: Business Relationships. Chapter 7 trustee could pierce the debtor's corporate veil and hold controlling officer liable for all amounts due creditors of the debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sloan v. Thornton
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Disregarding corporate structure to impose liability on shareholders or officers is extraordinary remedy undertaken only when necessary to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: Contract creditor of partnership brought suit against limited partner, seeking to impose personal liability.  Following jury verdict in favor of claimant, limited partner filed motion to set aside verdict as contrary to law and evidence and motion was granted.  During second trial the Circuit Court, Chesterfield County, Herbert C. Gill, Jr., J., entered judgment on jury verdict for limited partner and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Lacy, J., held that: (1) limited partner had not become general partner, through signing of guaranty; (2) limited partner was not liable for having taken a control position within partnership; (3) corporate veil would not be pierced so as to make limited partner liable due to his position as shareholder and director of corporation which was general partner; and (4) trial court was not required to instruct jury on theories of common-law partnership and joint entrepreneurship. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >

Potter, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) material issues of fact, precluding summary judgment, existed as to whether corporate veil should be pierced so as to reach assets of individuals; (2) corporate veil could be reached so that assets of holding company could be reached to satisfy obligations of subsidiary corporations; (3) wife of principal shareholder was a partner acting as principal in transactions in question, with corporations as her agent; (4) contractor had standing to sue corporations on a breach of fiduciary duty or negligent mismanagement theory; (5) material issues of fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on that...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Lebastchi v. Superior Court

Headnote: "Alter ego doctrine" arises when plaintiff claims opposing party is using corporate form unjustly and in derogation of plaintiff's interests.
Document Preview: Venue. Breach of contract action against corporation, wherein its principal was joined on alter ego theory, was properly venued.

Title: Doney v. TRW, Inc.

Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is strictly limited by demands of equity; it applies only in narrowly defined circumstances and only when ends of justice so require.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Black
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: Texas courts follow two-step test in determining alter ego: first step is to determine if there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and second step is to determine if failure to observe corporate formalities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. Chapter 7 debtor president of Chapter 11 debtor in possession, was not personally liable for DIP's breach of fiduciary duty and willful malicious acts in using proceeds from sale of secured inventory to pay other expenses while under duty to remit proceeds to secured creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Black
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in order to warrant piercing of corporate veil, courts generally require evidence that corporate entity amounts to fraud, promotes injustice, or is relied on to justify wrong, that corporation was inadequately capitalized, that individual controls or manages entity in such manner that it becomes his alter ego, or that corporate formalities were not adhered to by corporation.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. Chapter 7 debtor president of Chapter 11 debtor in possession, was not personally liable for DIP's breach of fiduciary duty and willful malicious acts in using proceeds from sale of secured inventory to pay other expenses while under duty to remit proceeds to secured creditor.

Headnote: Corporate form may be disregarded in interest of justice where it is used to defeat overriding public policy.
