Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Thomas v. Vertigo, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: Doctrine of disregarding corporate entity in certain circumstances is not limited to alter ego cases or cases involving fraud, but rather, extends to cases in which facts require court to disregard separate existence of corporation and shareholders in order to protect rights of third persons and accomplish justice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Corporate veil of insolvent corporation would be pierced to enforce workers' compensation judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: LaRose Market, Inc. v. Sylvan Center, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Court of Appeals will ignore corporate identity only where three prerequisites are satisfied: first, the corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual; second, the corporate entity must be used to commit fraud or wrong; and third, there must have been an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: Right of first refusal. Sale of stock of corporate landlord did not trigger tenant's right of first refusal.

Title: Estate of Daily v. Title Guar. Escrow Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Hawai‘i.
Headnote: Under Hawai"i law, corporate entity may be disregarded to prevent injustice and inequity, but Hawai"i appellate courts have historically been reluctant to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Mass
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, court may disregard legal fiction of corporate existence to facilitate an according of relief or adjudication of rights which is in line with general dictates of equity.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate, to make assets of debtor-shareholders' wholly owned corporation available for payment of creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Valley Mechanical Contractors, Inc. v. Gonzales
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded when fiction is used as means of perpetrating fraud, when corporation is organized and operated as mere tool or business conduit of another corporation, when corporate fiction is resorted to as means of evading existing legal obligation, when it is employed to achieve or perpetrate monopoly, when it is used to circumvent statute, and when it is relied upon as protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Corporation was mere alter ego of judgment debtor, whose bank accounts could be garnished.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Michigan State Painters Ins. Fund v. Ron Simmons Painting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil can be pierced if there are substantial reasons for doing so after weighing: (1) amount of respect given to separate entity of corporation by its shareholders; (2) degree of injustice visited on litigants by recognition of corporate entity; and (3) fraudulent intent of incorporators.
Document Preview: Employee benefit plans and labor union brought action under Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) against two painting contractors and their owners.  On motions for summary judgment by plans, union, first contractor, and first contractor's owner, the District Court, Gadola, J., held that: (1) fact issues existed as to whether contractors were joint employer, and (2) fact issues existed as to whether corporate veil of first contractor could be pierced so as to make its owner personally liable for contributions. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Aronson v. Price
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: While court will impose personal liability on shareholders to protect innocent third parties from fraud or injustice, burden is on party seeking to pierce corporate veil to prove that corporate form was so ignored, controlled, or manipulated that it was merely instrumentality of another and that misuse of corporate form would constitute fraud or promote injustice. West's A.I.C. 23-1-26-3(b).
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Shareholder was not personally liable for corporation's breach of contract and negligence, even though it failed to file assumed business name certificate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Al-Dabbagh v. Greenpeace, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil on the basis of alter ego doctrine, it must generally be shown that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that separateness of individual and corporation has ceased to exist and adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Female former employee brought action against former employer alleging that coemployee's rape of female former employee constituted sex discrimination in violation of Title VII.  Female former employee also asserted pendent Illinois state claims against former employer for assault, intentional infliction of emotional distress, negligent retention, negligent supervision, and negligent entrustment.  Former employer moved to dismiss complaint for failure to state a cause of action.  The District Court, Shadur, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) female former employee stated a cause of action under Title VII for discrimination on the basis of sex, and (2) exclusivity provisions of Illinois Workers' Compensation Act barred pendent state law claims. Motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Sheridan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To pierce veil of limited liability under Illinois law, two requirements must be satisfied: there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; and adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS. veil of limited liability would not be pierced to allow limited partners to proceed against Chapter 11 debtor or his estate to recover attorney fees and costs in defense of lawsuit brought by entities controlled by debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Jerry Martin & Associates, Inc. v. Don's Westland Bulk
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil is equitable remedy and applies only to prevent fraud or achieve equity.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor, who had default judgment against sole proprietorship, filed motion for order that it be allowed to levy and execute judgment against personal assets of owner of sole proprietorship.  The District Court of the Fifteenth Judicial District, Daniels County, M. James Sorte, J., denied motion.  Judgment creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Turnage, C.J., held that: (1) judgment creditor could not levy and execute against assets of sole proprietorship's owner under statute which provided that judgments against business associations would bind associates as if they had been named defendants; (2) judgment creditor could not levy and execute against assets of sole proprietorship's owner under theory of piercing corporate veil; and (3) judgment creditor could not levy and execute against assets of sole proprietorship's owner through use of misnomer rule. Affirmed. Trieweiler, J., dissented and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Gorsich v. Double B Trading Co., Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. IV.
Headnote: To establish alter ego doctrine, it must be shown that stockholders used corporate entity as mere instrumentality for transaction of their own affairs without regard to separate and independent corporate existence, or for the purpose of defeating or evading important legislative policy, or in order to perpetrate fraud or wrong on another.

Title: Dirksing v. Blue Chip Architectural Products, Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dirksing v. Blue Chip Architectural Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Twelfth District, Butler County.
Headnote: Corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by corporation when: (1) control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised to commit fraud or illegal action against person seeking to disregard corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from that control or wrong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Exclusivity provision of Workers' Compensation Act did not violate State Constitution.

Title: Thomas v. Peacock

The United States District Court for the District of South Carolina, George Ross Anderson, Jr. and William B. Traxler, Jr., JJ., approved piercing of corporate veil, holding officer personally liable for earlier judgment. Plaintiffs were also awarded attorney fees for both phases of the litigation. Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Sunshine Carpet Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Factors for determining whether alter ego doctrine has been satisfied are: amount of respect which shareholders give to separate entity; fraudulent intent involved; and amount of injustice which parties would suffer by respecting corporate entity.
Document Preview: Union pension funds brought suit seeking to recover contribution payments owed as part of collective bargaining agreement and under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA).  On cross motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Norgle, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to find that second corporation was alter ego of corporate employer and that its veil should be pierced to hold it liable for pension obligations of employer, and (2) piercing of corporate veil was not warranted under Illinois law to hold individual shareholders responsible for delinquent contributions. Plaintiffs' motion granted in part and denied in part; defendants' motion granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Chicago Dist. Council of Carpenters Pension Fund v. Sunshine Carpet Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, there are two requirements for piercing the corporate veil: there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and the individual no longer exist; and circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Union pension funds brought suit seeking to recover contribution payments owed as part of collective bargaining agreement and under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA). Title: Mark I, Inc. v. Gruber
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: While neglect of corporate forms is necessary for piercing corporate veil, it is not alone sufficient, and, in general there must also be evidence that managers or investors used corporate form to perpetrate injustice.
Document Preview: Corporation sued for conversion. The United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Rebecca R. Pallmeyer, United States Magistrate Judge, found that conversion had occurred and awarded damages. Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Easterbrook, Circuit Judge, held that the case had to be remanded for trial by a district judge where a corporate officer, joined in case after other parties had consented to decision by magistrate judge, did not explicitly consent to judge's role in proceeding. Vacated and remanded. Wellford, Circuit Judge, sitting by designation, filed concurring opinion.

Title: In re Pajaro Dunes Rental Agency, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: In deciding whether corporate veil should be pierced under California law, issue is not whether corporate entity should be disregarded for all purposes, or whether purpose of corporation was to defraud, but whether, in particular case presented and for purposes of such case, justice and equity can best be accomplished and fraud and unfairness defeated by disregard of distinct entity of corporate form.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. chapter 11 debtor did not receive reasonably equivalent value for its obligation to lender on note, through disbursement of loan proceeds to its corporate parent.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, court considers amount of respect given to separate identity of corporation by its shareholders, degree of injustice visited on litigants by recognition of corporate entity, and fraudulent intent of incorporator; party seeking to pierce corporate veil must prevail on first factor and on one of the other two.

Norris, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court was not required to obtain determination from National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) that employees of union and nonunion firms were appropriate bargaining unit; (2) district court had jurisdiction over ERISA claim; (3) union and nonunion firms were single employer;...

Title: In re Towe
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Montana.
Headnote: Under Nevada law, alter ego doctrine is equitable remedy where corporate entity is disregarded or pierced if (1) corporation is influenced and governed by person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there is such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) that adherence to fiction of separate entity of corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Towe

Headnote: Under Montana law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must first show that corporation is alter ego of individual and second must show that corporation was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud, keeping in mind that alter ego doctrine is equitable remedy to curb injustices resulting from improper use of corporate entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Faith Missionary Baptist Church
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Texas, Tyler Division.
Headnote: In Texas, legal fiction between individual and entity may be pierced if entity has been used as part of a basically unfair devise to achieve inequitable result.
Document Preview: TAX LEVIES. debtor-church was individual taxpayers' alter ego under Texas law, so that debtor's assets were subject to IRS tax levy to satisfy individual taxpayers' liabilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kansas Gas & Elec. Co. v. Ross
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Principal exception to limited liability rule for corporate shareholders is doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil," which is equitable in nature and which is used by courts to disregard distinction between corporation and its shareholders, to prevent fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against son of corporation's principals, seeking to pierce corporate veil of corporation and hold son individually liable for outstanding corporate debt.  The Fourth Judicial Circuit Court, Moody County, Tim D. Tucker, J., granted summary judgment in favor of son, and creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lovrien, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate principals' son, who held less than 1% of outstanding corporate stock, but who had signed two promissory notes to bank as treasurer of corporation, did not meet separate corporate identity prong for piercing veil of corporation. Affirmed. Sabers, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Title: Kansas Gas & Elec. Co. v. Ross
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: When notion that corporation is separate legal entity is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime, sufficient reason exists to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Kansas Gas & Elec. Co. v. Ross
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Two-part test is supplied in determining whether "piercing the corporate veil" is justified: whether there was such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and its shareholders, officers, or directors are indistinct or nonexistent; and whether adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud, promote injustice or inequitable consequences, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against son of corporation's principals, seeking to pierce corporate veil of corporation and hold son individually liable for outstanding corporate debt. The Supreme Court, Lovrien, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate principals' son, who held less than 1% of outstanding corporate stock, but who had signed two promissory notes to bank as treasurer of corporation, did not meet separate corporate identity prong for piercing veil of corporation. Affirmed. Sabers, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kansas Gas & Elec. Co. v. Ross
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Two factors that are considered in determining whether "fraud or inequitable consequence" prong of test for piercing corporate veil has been met are: fraudulent misrepresentation by corporation directors; and use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegalities.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against son of corporation's principals, seeking to pierce corporate veil of corporation and hold son individually liable for outstanding corporate debt. The Supreme Court, Lovrien, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate principals' son, who held less than 1% of outstanding corporate stock, but who had signed two promissory notes to bank as treasurer of corporation, did not meet separate corporate identity prong for piercing veil of corporation. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kansas Gas & Elec. Co. v. Ross
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Because veil piercing doctrine is equitable remedy, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must demonstrate that there has been substantial disregard for separate corporate identity and that there is some material equitable reason for court to hold shareholder, officer, or director personally liable; such "material equitable reason" might include fraud, injustice, or other inequitable consequences that result from disregard of separate corporate identity.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against son of corporation's principals, seeking to pierce corporate veil of corporation and hold son individually liable for outstanding corporate debt.  The Fourth Judicial Circuit Court, Moody County, Tim D. Tucker, J., granted summary judgment in favor of son, and creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lovrien, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate principals' son, who held less than 1% of outstanding corporate stock, but who had signed two promissory notes to bank as treasurer of corporation, did not meet separate corporate identity prong for piercing veil of corporation. Affirmed. Sabers, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kansas Gas & Elec. Co. v. Ross
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: To be charged personally with corporate liability, individual must have shared in moral culpability or injustice that is found to satisfy the "fraud, injustice, or inequitable consequences" prong of corporate veil piercing.

The Supreme Court, Lovrien, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate principals' son, who held less than 1% of outstanding corporate stock, but who had signed two promissory notes to bank as treasurer of corporation, did not meet separate corporate identity prong for piercing veil of corporation. Affirmed. Sabers, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Snyder v. Dunn
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Where a person seeks to pierce corporate veil to reach dominant individual, he must show that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and circumstances are such that adhering to fiction of separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequity, and to establish unity of interest, court looks to numerous facts, including whether corporation is inadequately capitalized, whether dominant individual has failed to observe corporate formalities in conducting his business, and whether corporate funds have been commingled with personal funds.
Document Preview: Partnership. Evidence was insufficient to establish existence of partnership between two physicians.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. for Use and Benefit of Skip Kirchdorfer, Inc. v. Aegis/Zublin Joint Venture
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division. .
Headnote: Decision to pierce corporate veil and impose liability on shareholders is extraordinary exception and should be permitted only when necessary to promote justice.
Document Preview: Subcontractor brought suit against contractor, its joint venture partner and Miller Act surety, seeking to enforce arbitration award in its favor in connection with excess cost claim for work done on military housing in Cuba. The District Court, MacKenzie, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) Federal Arbitration Act provision calling for enforcement of arbitration award in federal district in which arbitration award was entered, was permissive rather than mandatory; (2) arbitrator's decision was not irrational; and (3) award was enforceable against surety, even though surety claimed some components of award may have been items not recoverable under Miller Act. Award confirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: 1992 Republican Senate-House Dinner Committee v. Carolina's Pride Seafood, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: To prevail on alter ego claim under California law, claimant must show that there is such a unity of interest between corporation and individual that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and that inequitable results will follow if corporate separateness is respected.
Document Preview: Interpleader action was brought to determine ownership of funds contributed to political fund-raising committee.  On parties' cross-motions for summary judgment, the District Court, John H. Pratt, J., held that: (1) fraudulent conveyance statutes did not significantly impinge on First Amendment rights, and could be applied, without need for any heightened showing, to judgment debtors gift, during period of alleged insolvency, to political fund-raising committee; (2) judgment debtor did not receive reasonably equivalent value for contribution; but (3) material questions of fact precluded entry of summary judgment on parties' claims to corporate funds. Granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Winkler v. V.G. Reed & Sons, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: Just as equity permits piercing of corporate veil to reach assets of individual, it also permits piercing of subsidiary's corporate veil to reach assets of parent to protect innocent third parties from fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: Corporations. There was no basis to pierce corporate veil and hold sole shareholder liable for employment contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Southwest Livestock & Trucking Co. v. Dooley
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Legal fiction of corporate entity may be disregarded when there is such unity that separateness of corporation has ceased and adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would, under circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Alter Ego Doctrine. In divorce proceeding, wife could not use alter ego doctrine in order to place corporate assets in community estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Cammon Consultants Corp. v. Day
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2, Department B.
Headnote: When observance of corporate form would promote injustice, it will be disregarded.
Document Preview: Corporation sued holder of prior lien on certain real property, seeking to foreclose property tax liens which corporation had purchased from county.  The Superior Court, Pima County, Cause No. 285339, John F. Kelly, J., entered summary judgment for prior lienholder.  Corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Hathaway, J., held that: (1) corporation was alter ego of owner of subject property, and, as property owner was not entitled to foreclose tax liens, corporation was also precluded from doing so, and (2) prior lienholder was entitled to attorney fees. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Berlin v. Boedecker
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Before piercing corporate veil, trier of fact must find that defendant was either alter ego, instrumentality, or agent of corporation, and must find that corporate entity was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, or perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Action was brought against investment company and its principal shareholder for losses incurred by investors in two overriding royalty purchases.  The District Court, Eleventh Judicial District, County of Flathead, Joseph B. Gary, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs and defendants appealed.  The Supreme Court, Hunt, J., held that: (1) action was not barred by doctrine of res judicata or by doctrine of collateral estoppel; (2) amendment to complaint to add investment company as party defendant related back to date of filing of action and action was not barred by statute of limitations; (3) substantial credible evidence supported district court's findings of fact; and (4) district court did not err when it pierced corporate veil of investment company. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Washington Courte Condominium Association-Four v. Washington-Golf Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: For court to pierce corporate veil there must be such unity of interest in ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and circumstances must exist such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: Fraud. Developer's corporate officers were liable for fraud for failing to disclose water infiltration problem to condominium unit purchasers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Haskell v. Time, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Decision to pierce corporate veil is guided by amount of respect given to separate identity of corporation by its shareholders, degree of injustice visited on litigants by recognition of corporate entity, and fraudulent intent of incorporators.
Document Preview: Consumer brought action for injunctive relief, monetary damages, and attorney fees on behalf of himself and general public of California against publishers using sweepstakes entries to solicit magazine subscriptions, alleging false advertising, unfair business practices, illegal sweepstakes, and illegal lotteries.  On defendants' motions to dismiss, the District Court, Levi, J., held that: (1) exemplars of sweepstakes solicitations could be considered on motion to dismiss, despite not being included in complaint; (2) reasonable consumer rather than unwary consumer was appropriate standard in which to test claim of false or misleading advertising; (3) alleged misrepresentations were not misleading; (4) consumer failed to allege sufficient facts to pierce corporate veil of parent corporation as alter ego of magazine publisher; and (5) sweepstakes were not illegal contests or lotteries. Dismissed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Tomaselli v. Transamerica Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: To prevail on claim of alter ego, third party must show that there is such a unity of interest that the separate personalities of the corporations no longer exist and that inequitable results will follow if corporate separateness is respected.
Document Preview: Punitive Damages. Litigant cannot by inaction waive requirement of financial data as prerequisite to punitive damages award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Tomaselli v. Transamerica Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: If financial issues, corporate formality questions, ownership issues and commingling issues show a unity of interest and if it is also shown that honoring the corporate shell would promote fraud or injustice, third party may be permitted to pierce corporate veil and hold parent entity liable for corporate activities.
Document Preview: Punitive Damages. Litigant cannot by inaction waive requirement of financial data as prerequisite to punitive damages award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State ex rel. Oklahoma Employment Sec. Com'n v. Morrow
Court: Court of Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: In equitable proceeding, fiction of separateness between an individual and a corporation may be disregarded when it is necessary to prevent fraud, injustice or wrong.
Document Preview: Corporate Liability. Injunction was authorized to prevent corporate president from continuing to form corporations as a means of evading liability for unemployment tax.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Fentress v. Triple Min., Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District.
Headnote: To disregard corporate entity in absence of fraud, there must be facts indicating that adherence to corporate entity would promote injustice.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Corporate entity was properly disregarded to hold officers liable for promissory note.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Guyana Development Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, type of inequity or injustice that will warrant corporate veil piercing is much broader than strictly fraud.
Document Preview: TAX CLAIMS. IRS lacked standing to assert alter ego claims to recover debtor's tax liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Iemma v. Adventure RV Rentals, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana, Third District.
Headnote: Under certain circumstances where necessary to prevent fraud or injustice on innocent third parties, fiction of distinct corporate existence may be disregarded and the corporation held liable for acts of its shareholders, officers and directors.
Document Preview: Fire. Company was not innocent coinsured entitled to coverage for losses sustained as result of arson committed by its president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Killian v. McCulloch
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate form will only be disregarded in specific, unusual circumstances where it is necessary to prevent illegality, injustice or fraud, or where recognition of corporate entity would defeat public policy.
Document Preview: Class action was brought on behalf of employee/participants in profit sharing plan of defunct corporation against individual corporate officers alleging violations of ERISA and state law.  Defendants moved to dismiss complaint or for summary judgment.  The District Court, Joyner, J., held that: (1) profit sharing plan did not constitute employee pension benefit plan under ERISA; (2) allegations that corporate veil should be pierced in connection with remaining ERISA claim were sufficient to state claim against individual defendants for ERISA individual liability; (3) allegations seeking to pierce corporate shield under Pennsylvania law were also adequate in connection with state law claims; (4) participant/employees failed to allege all elements necessary to state claim under Pennsylvania law for tortious interference with contract; and (5) alleged violation of Pennsylvania Wage Payment and Collection Law (WPCL) had to be pled with...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Killian v. McCulloch
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, corporate veil will be pierced only where it is alleged that corporation was being used to perpetrate fraud or other crime, or where it is necessary to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: Class action was brought on behalf of employee/participants in profit sharing plan of defunct corporation against individual corporate officers alleging violations of ERISA and state law.  Defendants moved to dismiss complaint or for summary judgment.  The District Court, Joyner, J., held that: (1) profit sharing plan did not constitute employee pension benefit plan under ERISA; (2) allegations that corporate veil should be pierced in connection with remaining ERISA claim were sufficient to state claim against individual defendants for ERISA individual liability; (3) allegations seeking to pierce corporate shield under Pennsylvania law were also adequate in connection with state law claims; (4) participant/employees failed to allege all elements necessary to state claim under Pennsylvania law for tortious interference with contract; and (5) alleged violation of Pennsylvania Wage Payment and Collection Law (WPCL) had to be pled with...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: United Trade Associates Ltd. v. Dickens & Matson (USA) Ltd., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: English courts will lift corporate veil of limited liability only when corporate form is employed for purposes of fraud or as device to evade contractual or other legal obligations.
Document Preview: Ukrainian purchaser sued American seller and its president for, inter alia, breach of contract to provide telephones that complied with guidelines set by Ukrainian telephone commission.  The District Court, Anna Diggs Taylor, J., held that: (1) seller breached contract and various warranties; (2) seller's president was not individually liable; and (3) seller's drawing down on letter of credit opened by purchaser was not actionable under theory of negligent or innocent misrepresentation. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Envirotech Corp. v. Callahan
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: In order to disregard corporate entity under equitable alter ego doctrine: there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, but corporation is, instead, alter ego of one or a few individuals; and, if observed, corporate form would sanction fraud, promote injustice, or result in inequity.
Document Preview: Manufacturer of industrial filters brought suit against its former employee, seeking to recover its drawings and alleging misappropriation of trade secrets.  The Third District Court, Salt Lake County, John A. Rokich, J., issued preliminary injunction and later held defendant in contempt for violating it.  Defendant appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Bench, J., held that: (1) defendant did not have standing to challenge admission of evidence seized pursuant to writs; (2) statute of limitations did not bar plaintiff's claims; (3) plaintiff's detailed drawings constituted trade secrets; (4) plaintiff was entitled to trade secret protection; (5) defendant owed plaintiff a fiduciary duty that he breached by taking confidential materials with him when he left his employment; (6) trial court did not abuse its discretion in issuing preliminary injunction; (7) trial court properly held defendant in contempt for violating...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hyland Meat Co., Inc. v. Tsagarakis
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: As general rule, court will pierce corporate veil or disregard corporate form whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: Piercing Veil. Trial court properly pierced corporate veil to hold shareholders of restaurant corporation liable for debt owed by restaurant to meat deliverer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hyland Meat Co., Inc. v. Tsagarakis
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Concept of piercing corporate veil is equitable in nature, and decision whether to pierce veil in given instance will depend on facts and circumstances.
Document Preview: Piercing Veil. Trial court properly pierced corporate veil to hold shareholders of restaurant corporation liable for debt owed by restaurant to meat deliverer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bright v. Roadway Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To "pierce corporate veil" under Illinois law, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against former employer and former employer's parent corporation alleging race discrimination in violation of Title VII, retaliatory discharge, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.  The District Court, Alesia, J., held that: (1) parent corporation did not have notice that it was subject to discrimination action; (2) court had supplemental jurisdiction over state-law claims against parent corporation; and (3) allegations were insufficient to state claim for veil piercing against parent corporation. Ordered accordingly.
